componenttext: Can you talk about the step up, maybe in revenues, as you moved from copper to fiber in some of these offerings?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, so it's all demand-driven. So it's broadband, I mean 50 megs or 100 megs, that's how it's priced out. So the step up is significant, in that we currently have a copper piece in there and you move up into the fiber piece. We are maintaining current re
componenttext: Yes, so it's all demand-driven. So it's broadband, I mean 50 megs or 100 megs, that's how it's priced out. So the step up is significant, in that we currently have a copper piece in there and you move up into the fiber piece. We are maintaining current revenue as well as increasing new revenue. I think we've talked about, in the next couple of years, that'll give 1% to 2% on our total top line.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Think about it this way, John, is that we're signing guaranteed contracts of a fixed duration of anywhere from five to 10 years. So we know what our revenue generation is going to be. We know what our return is going to be, once we signed a contract and b
componenttext: Think about it this way, John, is that we're signing guaranteed contracts of a fixed duration of anywhere from five to 10 years. So we know what our revenue generation is going to be. We know what our return is going to be, once we signed a contract and before we put the first shovel into the ground. So this is great business and a great use, in return on our capital investments.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, to answer your second question around the -- this is where we are spending our capital. So the majority of our new growth is coming into fiber, and we're spending it at this spot as well as Fiber-to-the-Node, as well as fiber-to-building on the BMG
componenttext: John, to answer your second question around the -- this is where we are spending our capital. So the majority of our new growth is coming into fiber, and we're spending it at this spot as well as Fiber-to-the-Node, as well as fiber-to-building on the BMG side. So we take this fiber, run it down on particular street and serve all three of our business segments. So it's very efficient use of our capital.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Chris Larsen with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Chris Larsen with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, could you give us a sense for where you think the right leverage ratio should be for Qwest? And then Teresa, what is the gating factor on the Fiber-to-the-Node build? You talked about wanting to spend more on the Fiber-to-the-Tower. But it seems that
componenttext: Joe, could you give us a sense for where you think the right leverage ratio should be for Qwest? And then Teresa, what is the gating factor on the Fiber-to-the-Node build? You talked about wanting to spend more on the Fiber-to-the-Tower. But it seems that the DSL penetration or the high-speed Internet penetration worked much better there, and why wouldn't you push a little bit faster on the FTTN?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Look, on the answer to your leverage question, we continue to work towards moving to investment grade, down in the lower 2%. I think you see with all of the debt that'll get paid off here over the next 12 months, that helps us move there. And with our goa
componenttext: Look, on the answer to your leverage question, we continue to work towards moving to investment grade, down in the lower 2%. I think you see with all of the debt that'll get paid off here over the next 12 months, that helps us move there. And with our goal to turn the top line, it will help drive better EBITDA and therefore, give you a better ratio. So we're working at both sides of the equation.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, Chris, as far as on the Fiber-to-the-Node, we're still going to pass 1 million homes this year, new incremental homes. So this is an integrated build on the fiber where we are actually, as I mentioned, using all three business units to drive the
componenttext: And then, Chris, as far as on the Fiber-to-the-Node, we're still going to pass 1 million homes this year, new incremental homes. So this is an integrated build on the fiber where we are actually, as I mentioned, using all three business units to drive the build. And it is, like I said, still 1 million homes that we're going to pass. So we're pushing hard on Fiber-to-the-Node also.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Barden with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Barden with Bank of America.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, Joe, obviously you've set the goal of moving to investment grade metrics. But could you kind of give us an update now of what the conversations with the rating agencies are like? In as much as the business has improved so dramatically from a debt
componenttext: I guess, Joe, obviously you've set the goal of moving to investment grade metrics. But could you kind of give us an update now of what the conversations with the rating agencies are like? In as much as the business has improved so dramatically from a debt standpoint of last year, your outlook for the free cash flow and you're dealing with the converts is much improved, I have to imagine the rating agencies must be contemplating at least putting you on positive watch at this stage of the game. The second question was just related to you kind of say you don't want to talk about the pull in cash, but it kind of is the investment story for the equity is the cash and what the equity options are. When might we hear more from you on this topic? Do we have to wait until 2011? And how do you think about dividend taxes going up in that thought process?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, let me work backwards. So, Dave, how about if I promise you that no later than 2011, I'll talk to you about it. But the fact of the matter is -- just look, we've came off a pretty strong year in 2009 in stabilizing our EBITDA. And now our focus is t
componenttext: Well, let me work backwards. So, Dave, how about if I promise you that no later than 2011, I'll talk to you about it. But the fact of the matter is -- just look, we've came off a pretty strong year in 2009 in stabilizing our EBITDA. And now our focus is turning to the top line. And I think we need to sort of get a couple of quarters under of our belt and get the confidence level that that's in the sight to accomplish. SO when you look at our guidance, you see we're really trying to exit the year on a positive note, so that we can get to that 2011 growth story. And I think as you see that execution and you'll see the confidence happen, then you'll get more of a discussion about what had happened in the deployment of cash. And don't forget that the capital we're spending is to provide that proper return. So the whole Fiber-to-the-Cell and Fiber-to-the-Node, we've delivered on a consistent basis. And increasing our penetration levels of Fiber-to-the-Node will also help us generate the additional cash that you want us to deploy to our investors. In regards to the rating agencies, look, we have to had a good year. We clearly have had some preliminary talks with the rating agencies. Post our Analyst Day next week, we'll go back in and have some more formal talks. I'm not going to put words in their mouth but clearly with our execution, one would think that you'd look favorably at us.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: How do you think about dividend taxes going up and kind of how you want to manage that process?
componenttext: How do you think about dividend taxes going up and kind of how you want to manage that process?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's a little hard to manage per se -- I mean, yes, the dividend will be taxable this year, just as a result of the calculation. So it's really hard for me to predict whether we could get into a non-taxable situation. I'd probably predict it's probably go
componenttext: It's a little hard to manage per se -- I mean, yes, the dividend will be taxable this year, just as a result of the calculation. So it's really hard for me to predict whether we could get into a non-taxable situation. I'd probably predict it's probably going to be taxable.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Simon Flannery of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Simon Flannery of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ed, I wonder if you could just talk about Washington for a second. There's a lot of headlines about the upcoming broadband review and special access and other issues on the table. Can you just give us some perspective on how you're thinking about that? Ho
componenttext: Ed, I wonder if you could just talk about Washington for a second. There's a lot of headlines about the upcoming broadband review and special access and other issues on the table. Can you just give us some perspective on how you're thinking about that? How you can incorporate that into guidance? And then also, we've also seen some IPTV announcements, Cincinnati Bell last week, Bell Canada, the technology was really seems to be starting to improve right now, and the results have been encouraging. So what do you thinking about using the fiber network in terms of more video-type product-type from you or enabling others?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let's take Washington first, we continue to watch what's going on there. As you know, everybody can read. They're having trouble disbursing the first chunk of money. We are actively pursuing the second phase of this, and if we can make money at it, we thi
componenttext: Let's take Washington first, we continue to watch what's going on there. As you know, everybody can read. They're having trouble disbursing the first chunk of money. We are actively pursuing the second phase of this, and if we can make money at it, we think the rules have improved. All of our work we've done before, we will jump in there if we can make an adequate return and meet our hurdle rates. So I'd say we're cautiously optimistic about being able to participate. But there's still I think a lot of confusion, there's also not a clear strategy of what broadband would look like in the long toll, and what really is unserved or underserved, but more to come there. So we would all be upside for us, no downside. Secondly, on the IPTV front, as you know, that's the reason we built this architecture, was to take advantage of the continued movement of what I call ala carte video. We're still very bullish on that. We worked with people right now, it would be primarily an enablement. We would enable others. We closed down our video product, our retail video product in our two regions, which has been good for us. We would had to have a large capital spend to even upgrade it. And I really believe that this will continue, the momentum's hot and heavy. But I also think the other part of this that will make a huge difference is that we are seeing content people that are not traditional content people. And so I think that's also encouraging, and we've had contact with people in Silicon Valley, primarily California who have a little different model how to monetize this. I think there's more to come, which is both subscription and what I'd call an ad-based model. So I think it's coming faster than some would have predicted. And I think I saw a good news for us, Simon.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Simon, and everybody else in the call, we also want to mention that we will be filing our K probably today. And we will be providing some disclosure on access, revenues and cost. I know a lot of you have been interested in that area, with a lot of specula
componenttext: Simon, and everybody else in the call, we also want to mention that we will be filing our K probably today. And we will be providing some disclosure on access, revenues and cost. I know a lot of you have been interested in that area, with a lot of speculation going on about what's going to happen on pricing. So take a look at our K, and you'll see some new disclosures there.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brett Feldman from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brett Feldman from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: You guys did a great job talking about all of your revenue initiatives for the next year or two, but in the meantime, we just look at where your revenue guidance is. It's probably going to be a high-single digit decline for the year, but potentially flat
componenttext: You guys did a great job talking about all of your revenue initiatives for the next year or two, but in the meantime, we just look at where your revenue guidance is. It's probably going to be a high-single digit decline for the year, but potentially flat EBITDA. Can you talk a little bit about where some of your biggest cost initiatives are focused in the near term? Do you expect to continue managing the headcount the same way? And are there other areas where you think you still have some efficiency opportunities?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the one thing I want to say about costs is we manage it every day. So it's not a special project, process or things that we just queued temporarily. It really comes from two angles. One is matching the market to the workforce, so where we have areas wh
componenttext: So the one thing I want to say about costs is we manage it every day. So it's not a special project, process or things that we just queued temporarily. It really comes from two angles. One is matching the market to the workforce, so where we have areas where the market is declining, then we adjust the workforce, accordingly. The second piece is really just being more creative and innovative in how we run the company, from the things that I have mentioned around moving to the Internet. On the IT side, half of our development now occurs in our Bangalore Company. On the Network side, we've managed the facility cost very efficiently, constantly grooming ourselves and re-architecting ourselves to make our network the most efficient that it can be. So to answer your question, yes, we do believe there continues to be room and we continue to match the market conditions to the expense side and are confident that we can continue down that path.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the right interpretation that it's a little bit here and there, and not necessarily any large single line item, where you still think you have the most opportunity?
componenttext: So the right interpretation that it's a little bit here and there, and not necessarily any large single line item, where you still think you have the most opportunity?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think it's balanced across the board. I mean we go across our entire P&L and we challenge all of our expenses as we go out throughout the year. So it's not just a point in time, it's a day-to-day effort across all of the -- whether it's admin or ope
componenttext: No, I think it's balanced across the board. I mean we go across our entire P&L and we challenge all of our expenses as we go out throughout the year. So it's not just a point in time, it's a day-to-day effort across all of the -- whether it's admin or operating, sales and marketing, et cetera.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the Vijay Jayant with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the Vijay Jayant with Barclays Capital.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, just want to get some understanding on the correlation of CapEx to top line growth. Obviously, you said up to $1.7 billion and your growth from the top line seems to be down, mid- to high-single digit. If things go better, excluding obviously Fiber-t
componenttext: Joe, just want to get some understanding on the correlation of CapEx to top line growth. Obviously, you said up to $1.7 billion and your growth from the top line seems to be down, mid- to high-single digit. If things go better, excluding obviously Fiber-to-the-Cell and your Fiber-to-the-Node upgrades, can you start to talk about how much of the CapEx is truly variable?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, a portion of the capital is totally variable. We do clearly put in capital that is based on what we think subscribers will need as we grow our Business Markets Group, et cetera. So as the market continues to get better, we think we have enough room
componenttext: Well, a portion of the capital is totally variable. We do clearly put in capital that is based on what we think subscribers will need as we grow our Business Markets Group, et cetera. So as the market continues to get better, we think we have enough room in there to meet sort of demand for what we think the growth can be in the Business Market segment. And the other thing Vijay. I think the one thing you should know is that this year, because we're doing the integrated bill from Fiber-to-the-Cell and as a result of that row [ph] can hit the homes and hit he businesses, it's a far more efficient dollar being spent this year than was last year. And also in addition in 2009, we reduced the rates for what we pay on CapEx by some over $100 million. So we're getting also the additional benefit to that. So our capital this year is far more efficient in driving as far more than we have in historical years.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Vijay, about 50% of our capital is volume-driven. If not, I think of it at a high level. So it does gives us a lot of flexibility to be success based, and as volume moves up and down, we can move that budget accordingly, which is what we did this last yea
componenttext: Vijay, about 50% of our capital is volume-driven. If not, I think of it at a high level. So it does gives us a lot of flexibility to be success based, and as volume moves up and down, we can move that budget accordingly, which is what we did this last year and we'll continue to do that this year also.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Peter Rhamey with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Peter Rhamey with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to follow-up on the CapEx question, and one on EBITDA guidance. 2009 CapEx with leasing is $1.5 billion, you're going to $1.7 billion. Is that fair to say, Teresa, that most of the increase in capital spending here is maybe a small amount from Fiber-
componenttext: Just to follow-up on the CapEx question, and one on EBITDA guidance. 2009 CapEx with leasing is $1.5 billion, you're going to $1.7 billion. Is that fair to say, Teresa, that most of the increase in capital spending here is maybe a small amount from Fiber-to-the-Cell and the remainder is some assumption you made on the economy. Could you give some color on that? And the second question, EBITDA guidance. In 2009, EBITDA was down just over $100 million. And I'm just wondering looking forward, given you're getting a benefit on the OPEB, why you're forecasting flat-to-down EBITDA if you're keeping pressure on the costs lines?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: So on the incremental capital, you can assume that's all fiber. It's very fiber driven on all three segments though, in the consumer side, fiber to the node; in the wholesale, Fiber-to-the-Cell; and the business side, fiber-to-building customers locations
componenttext: So on the incremental capital, you can assume that's all fiber. It's very fiber driven on all three segments though, in the consumer side, fiber to the node; in the wholesale, Fiber-to-the-Cell; and the business side, fiber-to-building customers locations that's driven by that.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the way to look at it is look, we're going into 2010 with the goal of turning the top line. So it's early on, we're giving you early on guidance to what we think is going to happen and we can continue to update as we move throughout the year. If y
componenttext: I think the way to look at it is look, we're going into 2010 with the goal of turning the top line. So it's early on, we're giving you early on guidance to what we think is going to happen and we can continue to update as we move throughout the year. If you look at 2009, we have progress during the year. We continue to provide you better results than we have thought, and we upgraded our guidance on a going forward basis. I think we've look to deliver a pretty balanced approach. I think you've seen over 2009, a very consistent execution by the operating team, and we look for that going into 2010 and improving as we go through the year.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: It sounds like you're being conservative here with your guidance. I don't want to put words in your mouth, but it's also fair to say with your focus on revenue growth, I guess you're making some investments with hopefully a pay back in 2011. Is that how t
componenttext: It sounds like you're being conservative here with your guidance. I don't want to put words in your mouth, but it's also fair to say with your focus on revenue growth, I guess you're making some investments with hopefully a pay back in 2011. Is that how to also think about it?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, you are not going to grow the top line without making some sort of investment, and that's what we're committed to, is to get this company back to growth on the top line. Sure, we're cautiously optimistic, the economy hasn't turned around totally yet.
componenttext: Yes, you are not going to grow the top line without making some sort of investment, and that's what we're committed to, is to get this company back to growth on the top line. Sure, we're cautiously optimistic, the economy hasn't turned around totally yet. Unemployment is still high, bankruptcies are still high both on a personal and business level. So we're trying to be cautious and not get out ahead of our skis as we go forward in the start of this year.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Dave Coleman with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question comes from Dave Coleman with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm just wondering if you can talk about access line trends, of that 20 basis point quarter-to-quarter improvement and the rate of loss. I'm just wondering if that improvement is from reduced churn or increased gross adds or a mix of the two? And then on
componenttext: I'm just wondering if you can talk about access line trends, of that 20 basis point quarter-to-quarter improvement and the rate of loss. I'm just wondering if that improvement is from reduced churn or increased gross adds or a mix of the two? And then on the IT Services business, can you talk about how much of that growth is coming from new versus existing customers. I know it's not a one-for-one  exchange, but I was wondering if a decline in Legacy business is translating into an equal amount increased in the IP Services business.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: As far as access line trends, I would attribute mostly to churn. There's not a lot of new activity going on as you watched the consumer market, there's not a lot of new growth in there. So the majority of that change that you saw was based on churn, and o
componenttext: As far as access line trends, I would attribute mostly to churn. There's not a lot of new activity going on as you watched the consumer market, there's not a lot of new growth in there. So the majority of that change that you saw was based on churn, and our bundling services and keeping the customer on the package that we offer. As far as IP services, there's a combination of existing customers upgrading on their bandwidth, which we're very happy with, because that drives the ARPU as well as there are some new customers coming into that at a lower bandwidth. In my comments, I mentioned there's still a good chunk of our market that doesn't any form of broadband services. So it's really a combination of both of them. And we have a very concerted effort to upgrade our base and to move our base into the broadband base.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Todd Rethemeier with Hudson Square Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Todd Rethemeier with Hudson Square Research.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give us a little more color on the fiber to the node? Remind us of the home's path [ph] at this past point, and what kind of penetration rates are you seeing or adoption rates that you are seeing in some of the markets that have been up for a whil
componenttext: Can you give us a little more color on the fiber to the node? Remind us of the home's path [ph] at this past point, and what kind of penetration rates are you seeing or adoption rates that you are seeing in some of the markets that have been up for a while with the higher speed product?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: So currently, we have passed 3 million at home -- 3.5 million, I'm sorry in fiber to the node. And our plans for 2010 are to build, pass another 1 million. So it will be up to 4.5 million at a minimum, I would say. As far as the penetration levels, it var
componenttext: So currently, we have passed 3 million at home -- 3.5 million, I'm sorry in fiber to the node. And our plans for 2010 are to build, pass another 1 million. So it will be up to 4.5 million at a minimum, I would say. As far as the penetration levels, it varies quite a bit by market. So it really depends if we were already there with the lower speed and we're overlaying or for going into a new market. And our geography is quite diverse. So depending on what the competition looks like across-the-board.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Frank Louthan with Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Frank Louthan with Raymond James.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Mike Ciaccia for Frank. You mentioned the converts earlier, can you talk a little bit about the parameters you put about buying those back? And then on the Wholesale trends was that primarily driven by pricing or lower MOUs? Any color there would
componenttext: This is Mike Ciaccia for Frank. You mentioned the converts earlier, can you talk a little bit about the parameters you put about buying those back? And then on the Wholesale trends was that primarily driven by pricing or lower MOUs? Any color there would be great?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: For the Wholesale piece, can you just clarify, are you talking about the total revenue or the long-distance piece or what you were referencing there?
componenttext: For the Wholesale piece, can you just clarify, are you talking about the total revenue or the long-distance piece or what you were referencing there?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just the Wholesale in general.
componenttext: Just the Wholesale in general.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the two pressure points in Wholesale are long-distance, yes. As we were driving minutes against the network that weren't profitable. And the second pressure point in the revenue was in the local access side and that is from declining minutes also.
componenttext: So the two pressure points in Wholesale are long-distance, yes. As we were driving minutes against the network that weren't profitable. And the second pressure point in the revenue was in the local access side and that is from declining minutes also.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I think, in regard to your last question, the fact is we have a lot of cash on our balance sheet right now, and we want to put it to productive use, and that's why we called to pattern [ph] the 525 million of notes that were on schedule to mature to 2
componenttext: And I think, in regard to your last question, the fact is we have a lot of cash on our balance sheet right now, and we want to put it to productive use, and that's why we called to pattern [ph] the 525 million of notes that were on schedule to mature to 2011. So if the right economic deal could be struck to call the converts back earlier, we would clearly take advantage of that. Operator, so I think that concludes our Q&A session. So thank you so much everyone, for joining the call, and we look forward to having you come to our Analyst Day in a week.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, this does conclude today's presentation. You may now disconnect.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, this does conclude today's presentation. You may now disconnect.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, my name is Kevin, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Qwest Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Fawkes, you may begin your conference.
componenttext: Good morning, my name is Kevin, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Qwest Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Fawkes, you may begin your conference.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Kevin. Good morning, everybody, and welcome to our call. We appreciate your interest in Qwest. I'm enjoyed by Ed Mueller, our Chairman and CEO; Teresa Taylor, our COO and Joe Euteneuer, our CFO. We'll begin today's call with a few comment
componenttext: Okay. Thank you, Kevin. Good morning, everybody, and welcome to our call. We appreciate your interest in Qwest. I'm enjoyed by Ed Mueller, our Chairman and CEO; Teresa Taylor, our COO and Joe Euteneuer, our CFO. We'll begin today's call with a few comments on the quarter from Ed and then Teresa will provide a review of business unit results. Joe will conclude our prepared remarks with a discussion of our consolidated financial results and the 2010 outlook. We will then open it up for your questions.As we begin our call, let me point you to Slide 3 and remind everyone that today's discussion contains forward-looking statements. These statements are subject to significant risks and uncertainties. These risks and uncertainties are discussed in detail on our periodic filings with the SEC, and I strongly encourage you to thoroughly review them. Additionally, we do not adopt analyst estimates nor that we necessarily commit to updating forward-looking statements that we're going to be making this morning. Also, let me mention that in order to supplement the reporting of our consolidated financial information, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures including adjusted EBITDA, adjusted free cash flow and net debt. A full reconciliation of these majors is available on our website.Moving on to Slide 4. Earnings per share for the quarter was $0.06 compared to $0.10 in the fourth quarter of 2008. Current quarter earnings include a $0.02 charge for severance costs. The year-ago period includes a $0.01 charge for severance. Full year reported earnings per share for 2009 was $0.38, and that compares to $0.37 for 2008. One-time charges for severance and litigation in 2009 netted to zero. The prior year includes net charges of $0.03 per share from a combination of severance, realignment litigation and property tax settlements. In addition to these adjustments, 2009 reported earnings have been impacted by dilution from incremental non-cash pension and OPEB expense. In the current quarter, this dilution was $0.02 per share and the full year impact is $0.07. With that, I'm going to turn it over to Ed. Ed?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kurt. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I want to begin by saying we're very pleased with our financial performance for both the quarter and for the full year. Under challenging economic conditions and competitive pressur
componenttext: Thanks, Kurt. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I want to begin by saying we're very pleased with our financial performance for both the quarter and for the full year. Under challenging economic conditions and competitive pressures, we delivered strong cash flows, improved margins and we made great progress on several key initiatives to drive long-term shareholder value. Throughout the course of 2009, we delivered solid growth in our strategic revenues, and we are pleased with the increasing margins for these services. Our Business Markets Group had very good relative performance in the fourth quarter and throughout 2009. As far as our overall revenues, we would have liked to have reported better growth. However, I would point out that in addition to a tough economy, our reported revenues were also impacted by our initiatives to improve profitability. These include our move to a new wireless business model, which accounted 30% of our revenue decline and the elimination of poor margin wholesale long-distance revenue. While these initiatives will continue to impact our reported comparisons for the next couple of quarters, we should have easier comps in the second half of the year. Our efforts to improve margins was another area where we had strong success in 2009. For the full year, our adjusted EBITDA margin was at its best level since the merger with U.S. West in 2000. Adjusted free cash flow generated for the year was also at its highest level since the merger. Our performance continues to demonstrate that our initiatives are working, and we are carrying this momentum into 2010. In the fourth quarter, we improved our revenue mix and continue to transition away from a legacy revenue base. This transition is supported by our state-of-the-art nationwide network. This is a tremendous asset that delivers best-in-class services to businesses and government agencies throughout the country and supports all of our fiber deployment strategies. Much of our margin improvement in 2009 was from these services, and we remain focused on leveraging growth from this asset. Over the course of the year, we continued to make progress in enhancing our market position by delivering on simplified integrated solutions, improving partnerships and expanding broadband capabilities. Mid-year, we announced a five-year extension to our strategic partnership with DIRECTV. In addition, we jointly launched a new suite of integrated services to maximize the combination of DIRECTV and Qwest high-speed Internet. We've also made progress on our wireless partnership and in the fourth quarter, we concluded a very successful transition to the Verizon Wireless reseller model. Finally, we continue to deploy Fiber-to-the-Node reaching more than 3.5 million homes at year and serving 420,000 subscribers. Our broadband initiatives remain a top priority as we look to 2010. We have had some early success in marketing our Fiber-to-the-Cell Site products, and we expect to build on this momentum in 2010. To drive transport efficiencies, we announced plans to upgrade our backbone capacities to 100 gigabit speed, and we will continue to deploy Fiber-to-the-Node across our residential footprint. In 2009, we strengthened our balance sheet. Despite a tough capital markets environment, especially early in the year, we were able to access the credit markets at favorable rates. We also announced the new four-year revolving credit facility. Collectively, these actions has significantly improved our maturity profile and enhanced our financial flexibility. Finally, we remain committed to our balanced approach to investment returns. For all of 2009, our direct shareholder returns in the form of cash dividends were $550 million. In addition, we reduced net debt by $1.2 billion during the year. To some up, I think we had a solid year at nearly every level of the company. The Qwest team's ability to deliver these results in tough markets has really been quite remarkable throughout 2009. In 2010, you will continue to see the results of our efforts to improve efficiency and productivity, and we will remain dedicated focused on the top line. Now I'll hand it off to Teresa who will discuss our business unit performance.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ed. Good morning, everyone. I'm pleased to give you an update on our operations. In the fourth quarter, we maintained solid operating performance. Overall, we continued to see strong demand for broadband strategic products, which grew 4% for th
componenttext: Thank you, Ed. Good morning, everyone. I'm pleased to give you an update on our operations. In the fourth quarter, we maintained solid operating performance. Overall, we continued to see strong demand for broadband strategic products, which grew 4% for the quarter and 6% for the full year. This was driven by 37% full year growth in enterprise IP services and higher take rates for fiber-based consumer broadband services. We also remain disciplined in our expense control. This focus produced margin gains across all three segments, a significant accomplishment in light of challenging market conditions.In 2009, we demonstrate that we can adjust to the market and manage the bottom line. In the coming year, our goals are to improve our revenue trajectory while retaining a bottom-line discipline. As we turn to 2010, we see encouraging signs in each of our segments.Let's start with the Business Markets segment on Slide 8. Results reflect our continued success in growing our strategic revenues and expanding our margins. Business Markets reported total revenues of $1 billion in the fourth quarter. In the quarter, Business Markets revenue performance outpaced major competitors although revenue decreased 2% from the fourth quarter of 2008 and declined 1% sequentially. As we have previously noted, a key metric we monitor is recurring service revenue. In the fourth quarter, recurring revenues were down 1% year-over-year and were flat with the third quarter. For the full year, recurring revenues were modestly ahead of 2008.Strategic revenues within Business Markets increased 7%, compared to the fourth quarter of 2008. This is driven by strong demand for our MPLS IP services, which increased 26%. In the quarter, strategic revenues were 40% of total business revenue, an increase from 36% a year ago.In the fourth quarter, legacy revenues declined 8% compared to a year ago due to lower vocal voice revenues and legacy LAN data services. As customers continue to migrate to next-generation services. This was partially offset by growth in demand for call center applications and we are deep in the transition of the customers from legacy data transport services such as ATM and frame relay.Revenues from those services we're under 6% of total Business Market revenue in the fourth quarter compared to 8% a year ago. The decline in data integration revenue in the quarter reflects lower equipment sales, partially offset growth in demand for professional services. In the fourth quarter, Business Market segment income of $405 million improved 3% year-over-year but declined 1% sequentially. Segment income for the full year improved 7%, primarily due to channel efficiencies and lower network and facility spend.For 2010, our plans four Business Market is to build up success for the past year. We have a diverse customer portfolio we offer unique support and have a strong mix of managed and next-generation data IP services. The key strengths provide a strong foundation four us to grow our enterprise top line as the economy improves in coming quarters.Results for our wholesale segment are summarized on Slide 9. Wholesale results reflect an improved strategic product mix and continued progress on improving profitability. Revenue for the quarter told at $679 million. This is an annual decline of 14% and a sequential decline of 3%. In the quarter, strategic revenues were stable and increased to 45% of total wholesale revenue from 39% a year ago. Legacy revenue decreased 22% year-over-year and 6% sequentially. The annual decline was in part due to proactively managing long-distance profitability. The sequential decline was mainly due to ongoing local voice and access revenue pressure. In the quarter, long-distance revenue, which was a little under 20% of total Wholesale segment revenues, declined by more than 30% from the quarter of 2008. Even with the significant decrease, the profit contribution from long-distance was relatively flat with the year ago.Segment income for the quarter was $447 million, an 8% decline from a year ago and a 3% sequential decline. Segment margin was 65.8%, a 410 basis point improvement from the fourth quarter of 2008. Margins improved to 660 basis points for the full year. In 2010, we expect Wholesale long-distance revenue comparisons will improve beginning in the second quarter. Our Wholesale group continues to seize the opportunity to leverage our broadband fiber investments, and capitalize on growing demand for wireless backhaul services. We currently have contracts to provide fiber-based access to nearly 2,000 wireless cell sites. These contracts provide an avenue for strategic revenue growth, while protecting existing copper backhaul services. We will begin to recognize revenues in 2010. However, the full year impact will be minor. Over the next couple of years, this could add 1% to 2% to our annual consolidated revenue.Now we'll turn to Mass Markets results on Slide 10. As Ed mentioned, we completed the migration to our new wireless reseller business model during the quarter. Excluding the impact of this transition, Mass Markets revenue for the quarter declined 7% year-over-year and 1% sequentially. Strategic revenues improved 3% sequentially and 4% year-over-year. In the quarter, strategic revenue was 30% of total Mass Markets revenue compared to 25% a year ago. In the fourth quarter, legacy revenue declined due to lower demand for traditional local voice services. Segment income of $685 million declined 7% compared to the fourth quarter of 2008. On a sequential basis, expense reductions outpaced revenue declines, and this drove a 2% improvement in segment income and a 220 basis point improvement in margin. For the full year, segment income was down 3% as a result of continued top line pressure. It was offset by substantial expense reductions. And for the full year, margins improved to 550 basis points. Our quarterly subscriber results are contained on Slide 11. We made solid progress on retention efforts during the quarter. In fact, the absolute number of consumer access line losses is at the lowest level in two years. We also continue to grow the revenues from customers we retain. Consumer ARPU improved during the quarter to $60, up 6% compared to the fourth quarter of 2008. Next, broadband subscriber additions were 23,000 for the quarter, and we ended the year with nearly 3 million subscribers. Our fiber investments continue to pay dividends. In the quarter, we added 80,000 new subscribers on fiber. We ended the period with 420,000 broadband fiber subscribers, or about 14% of our total high-speed Internet customers.On average, FTTN customers generate a 15% less in ARPU compared to DSL customers. And therefore, we believe migrations, alone, provide a great growth opportunity. In addition, about 35% of households in our territory, or about 4 million homes, do not have any high-speed Internet service today. This also represents an opportunity for us.We achieved solid performance in bundled services in the quarter, and we enhanced subscriber retention through our video and wireless service offering. In the quarter, we added 23,000 DIRECTV subscribers. These additions were partially offset by the elimination of 5,000 Qwest legacy video customers.  In efforts to wind down the Qwest-branded video in Arizona and Colorado are now complete. In the fourth quarter, we had success in acquiring new Verizon Wireless customers and moving existing subscribers to a single bill offered by Qwest. In total, we increased the number of Qwest-billed Verizon users by 64,000 in the quarter, and ended the year with 850,000 total customers.In 2010, our Mass Markets group is focused on acquiring and retaining customers by providing a differentiated customer experience. As a result of our initiatives, we are seeing early signs of success. For example, our new on-boarding process for consumer broadband users has increased install rates and improved take rates on value-added services. Additionally, we have implemented a new regional operating structure. This creates new customer touch points, while enhancing our ability to drive market-based solutions. Before I close, I want to touch on our ongoing efforts to match our work-force to work-load, which is depicted on Slide 12. Our total employee count declined by more than 1,200 in the fourth quarter, and by 2,800 or 8% for the full year. The vast majority of fourth quarter reductions occurred in the latter stages of the quarter. And while these were difficult decisions, I am confident that we will continue to provide a superior customer experience. In closing, I am pleased with our execution for the quarter and full year. In one of the most difficult economic times, we remained disciplined and actively managed resources to reflect market conditions. We successfully grew strategic revenue and associated margins, while driving expenses out of the legacy business. In 2010, we will continue to focus on growth through disciplined investment. I look forward to meeting many of you and providing more details on our progress and future plans at our upcoming investment community meeting. Now I will turn it over to Joe.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Teresa. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us on the call. I am pleased to report that this was another quarter of consistent performance, and we finished with strong results for the year. We delivered solid EBITDA, improved marg
componenttext: Thank you, Teresa. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us on the call. I am pleased to report that this was another quarter of consistent performance, and we finished with strong results for the year. We delivered solid EBITDA, improved margins and generated strong free cash flow, despite unprecedented market conditions. We successfully access the capital markets during the year and in doing so, we eliminated refinancing risks for the foreseeable future while improving our financial flexibility. We continue to provide a balanced mix of returns for our shareholders, including paying out $550 million in dividends, reducing net debt levels by $1.2 billion and investing $1.5 billion of capital back into the business. This investment will fund future growth and return for our shareholders. Now I'd like to turn to the income statement on Slide 14. In the fourth quarter, consolidated net operating revenues of $3 billion declined 10% compared to the prior year. Without the impacts of the wireless transition, revenues declined only 7%. Teresa provided you some sense of the efforts on our reported top line associated with our efforts to improve Wholesale long-distance margins. For the full year, revenue declined 9% or 6% after adjusting for the wireless MVNO transition. Consolidated strategic services revenue improved 4% in the quarter and 6% for the full year. We continue to improve our revenue mix by shifting to fiber-based initiatives and IP-based data solutions. In the quarter, strategic revenue accounted for 36% of total revenue versus 31% a year ago. Total operating expenses improved 1% sequentially, and 8% year-over-year. For the full year, total expenses improved 9%. The improved operating cost in the quarter and for the full year are driven by our continued efforts to increase operating efficiency through innovative process improvement, increased productivity and lower unit cost for purchase goods and services.Fourth quarter adjusted EBITDA was $1.09 billion compared with $1.18 billion a year ago. The adjusted EBITDA margin improved 60 basis points for the same period. The current quarter includes $44 million of incremental non-cash pension and OPEB expense compared to prior year's quarter. For the full year, adjusted EBITDA was $4.4 billion on a margin of 35.9%. Excluding the impact of incremental non-cash pension and OPEB expense of $210 million, the margin improved 390 basis points for the year. On this same basis, we would have reported 2% growth in full year adjusted EBITDA. The improved profitability was mainly due to the transition to a new wireless business model and improved revenue mix in Wholesale and substantial reductions in direct channel expense and overhead cost.Moving on to Slide 15. We continue to strengthen the balance sheet in the fourth quarter and improve our financial flexibility. As a result of our strong free cash flows, we ended the year with net debt of $11.8 billion compared to $13 billion at the end of 2008. Cash and cash equivalents increased to $2.4 billion from $565 million a year ago. Net debt to annualize adjusted EBITDA was 2.7x at year end, a significant improvement from the year-ago period. During the quarter, we completed a new four-year revolving credit facility which was upsized to $1.04 billion and it currently remains undrawn. In January of 2010, we issued $800 million of notes with a coupon of 7.125%. While our success in the capital markets has substantially removed refinancing risks, we are all also taking efforts to put these resources to productive use, calling $525 million of notes that were scheduled to mature in February 2011.Finally, we may decide to call our $1.27 billion convertible debt later this year. These actions, along with our planned redemptions over the next 12 months, would reduce total debt by nearly $3.5 billion. This will further improve our net debt-to-EBITDA ratio. Details on adjusted free cash flow and capital expenditures are shown on Slide 16. In the quarter, we continued to maintain a strong management of receivables and payables. Both DSOs and DPOs improved year-over-year. Our collection staff has done an outstanding job all year for us. Bad debt expense was 0.6% of revenue in the quarter, and 1.1% for the full year. Adjusted free cash flow for the quarter was $506 million and it was $1.9 billion for the full year. Strong EBITDA, lower capital expenditures and working capital contributions drove these results. Capital expenditures were $386 million in the quarter. Capital spending for the full year totaled $1.4 billion, plus we leased capital of a little over $100 million. This compares to capital spending of $1.8 billion in 2008. The principal reasons for our lower capital expenditures are lower customer demand, moderation of network traffic growth and lower requirements associated with the slowdown in new housing construction. We also benefited from our efforts within our purchasing, engineering and operations group, which have produced vendor savings, improved inventory levels and lowered our capital unit cost.Now I'd like to close my remarks with a discussion on guidance, on Slide 17. In 2009, we focused our efforts in the guidance we provided on EBITDA and free cash flow. We realized we cannot simply cut cost to achieve long-term prosperity. In addition, the markets are starting to stabilize and therefore, we feel the time is appropriate to provide some guidance commentary on our efforts to improve the top line. For the near term, we continue to see a stable outlook for Business Markets, with revenue continuing to beat industry averages. In Wholesale, we are likely to continue to report significant year-over-year declines, but as Teresa noted, the Wholesale long-distance comparisons should start to improve beginning in the second quarter. Mass Markets revenue in the short run will continue to follow access line trends, partially offset by increased ARPU from bundled services and growth in high-speed Internet subscribers. In looking at overall consolidated revenues, we expect that our year-over-year comparisons will improve over the course of the year.As a reminder, there was a little over $100 million of wireless MVNO revenues that we reported in the first three quarters of 2009 that won't be repeated in 2010. Our goal is to reduce our year-over-year revenue declines to a low to mid-single digit rate by the fourth quarter of this year. We will continue to be keenly focused on efficiently managing our business to maintain or improve margins. We expect adjusted EBITDA to be in the range of $4.3 billion to $4.4 billion. We are expecting non-cash pension and OPEB expense to be approximately $130 million in 2010, which would be a $70 million improvement from 2009. The outlook for capital investment is $1.7 billion or less. We may use lease financing in 2010 for some portion of this capital spending. Our capital spending program will perfect our opportunity in  Fiber-to-the-Cell, while we continued to invest in Fiber-to-the-Node on an integrated basis. The combination of continued solid cash flows from operating activities and strong investment in the business is expected to produce adjusted free cash flow of $1.5 billion to $1.6 billion for the full year 2010. We do not expect to make any funding contributions to the pension plan in 2010. In 2011, we believe our pension funding requirements could be in the range of zero to $120 million, but the information necessary to finalize our contribution calculations will not be available until later in 2010. On the subject of cash taxes, our available NOLs continue to limit federal cash tax payments to the alternative minimum tax, which is approximately 2%. We currently expect this will be the case for approximately the next five years. It is our current expectation that we will continue to pay a quarterly dividend of $0.08 per share in 2010. For now, we are deferring on any additional comments on our free cash flow allocations beyond these dividends and paying off unregulated debt maturities. We will continue to assess the best use of future excess cash flows, including reinvestments back into the business, stock buybacks, dividend increases and additional deleveraging actions. In closing, I'd like to reiterate how pleased I am with 2009 results. The Qwest team has consistently demonstrated its ability to drive productivity and efficiency to improve EBITDA and free cash flow despite a challenging environment. This success has been achieved against a backdrop of high unemployment rates, competition from wireless, more aggressive promotions from cable service providers and continued business weakness with low levels of investment. We are looking forward to applying our considerable capabilities under better market conditions in the month ahead. Before I turn the call over to the operator for questions, Ed, Teresa and I along with the management team would like to congratulate the workforce for a job well done in 2009, and thank them for all their hard work. With that, I'll turn the call back over to the operator and open up the line for questions.

If you can give us a balance of the two. And then also as you're going through that, maybe just update on the pricing environment.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Teresa. As far as where we're taking share, it's really in the data and IP space from a product perspective. And it's generally appear right below the Fortune 100. So it's been the spot where we continue to be successful in. And I would also say t
componenttext: This is Teresa. As far as where we're taking share, it's really in the data and IP space from a product perspective. And it's generally appear right below the Fortune 100. So it's been the spot where we continue to be successful in. And I would also say that our success is based on retention. So where we've had that growth of last year was really based on holding on to our existing customers, growing them inside an account. And then, acquiring new account. As far as pricing, I think you ask that also. It's pretty stable. I mean, we don't see anything that's too crazy out there. And I would say, like always you have a couple individual companies that might focus on a particular counter, particular product. But in general, it feels pretty stable.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mike McCormack of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike McCormack of JPMorgan.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Scott Goldman, on for Mike McCormack. First, on the Mass Market margins, I saw a nice step up there. Wondering if there's some additional wireless cost that had kind of come out that led to that, and whether that's kind of a sustainable level, or
componenttext: This is Scott Goldman, on for Mike McCormack. First, on the Mass Market margins, I saw a nice step up there. Wondering if there's some additional wireless cost that had kind of come out that led to that, and whether that's kind of a sustainable level, or whether there was some lower selling or headcount that really drove that margin improvement. And then maybe Teresa, if you could just expand a little bit on the previous question. Just talk about some of the puts and takes for both Business and Wholesale. I know you gave some comments on Wholesale improving beginning into second quarter, but I just kind of seem [ph] a little bit more of the details behind some of the puts and takes on Business and Wholesale 2010?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: So like on the Mass Markets, on the consumer side, it was not the Wireless piece. We're pretty much done with that earlier. So the list up that you saw in the fourth quarter was driven by efficiencies. One example, if we went to the regional structure, I
componenttext: So like on the Mass Markets, on the consumer side, it was not the Wireless piece. We're pretty much done with that earlier. So the list up that you saw in the fourth quarter was driven by efficiencies. One example, if we went to the regional structure, I think that I described before, and that actually took cost out, which I know sounds color-intuitive. But that gave us a chance to focus locally on individual markets, and remove some layers and some pieces of management there. And the second driver was we are efficiently moving our customers online. So as much as we can, we are moving sales channel through an online structure as well as support. So those are the drivers. So to answer your question, it is sustainable. That was not just driven by the Wireless piece. BMG and Wholesale, as I commented earlier, we expect BMG to continue to pace along as it had. And actually assuming a bit of an uptick there as the economy improves. We are seeing signs of customer starting to move, even though they didn't make many decisions last year. I think now they're in a position where they have to expend their data network, and they have to expand their broadband efforts. And we plan on being there, where I think we've been very good at focusing on the products that we're good at in the space that we're good as far as the segmentation. On the Wholesale side, any growth that comes, they will be from Fiber-to-the-Cell. We are very excited that we're already at 2,000 cell sites that are under contract. And there's many more behind that. That's a very big number for us. And we know we can deliver. We're very good at fiber buildouts, and this is our spot. It also allows us to retain the copper backhaul that we offer today, to those wireless providers. For long-distance revenue and Wholesale, I think we'll continue to stabilize. We've been through the rough part where we create the margins largest that we want and now, we'll keep that stable.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2010
