componenttext: Our next question comes from John Hodulik from UBS.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Just quickly on the Business Market. Looks like we may have hit a sort of soft patch in the economy here. Any suggestion that the improvement that we've been seeing could stall out? Or along with that, any changes in the competitive environment in that pa
componenttext: Just quickly on the Business Market. Looks like we may have hit a sort of soft patch in the economy here. Any suggestion that the improvement that we've been seeing could stall out? Or along with that, any changes in the competitive environment in that part of the market you're seeing?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: So John, no change in the competitive environment. Almost everybody is still in the same place. But I would call it stable right now. It's not improving in the way I think everyone had hoped, but it's not declining. So it's fairly stable, and it's somewha
componenttext: So John, no change in the competitive environment. Almost everybody is still in the same place. But I would call it stable right now. It's not improving in the way I think everyone had hoped, but it's not declining. So it's fairly stable, and it's somewhat been the recovery I think is being dragged down a little bit. That's what we're seeing. And the fact is unemployment is still a driver, and this unemployment isn't changing on the businesses.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Michael Rollins from Citi Investment Research.
componenttext: The next question comes from Michael Rollins from Citi Investment Research.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: So just to follow up on the costs side. As you think of the longevity of the success you've had, you had two years now where you've been able to generally maintain OIBDA pre-pension changes relative to some meaningful declines in revenue. And as you look
componenttext: So just to follow up on the costs side. As you think of the longevity of the success you've had, you had two years now where you've been able to generally maintain OIBDA pre-pension changes relative to some meaningful declines in revenue. And as you look out, maybe not just over the next six months but we think more 18 months to 36 months, how do you think about the opportunity for Qwest to sustain that level of productivity and taking cost out relative to the revenue? Then maybe either some numbers or some arithmetic you could help us think about in terms of what every dollar or revenue could mean in terms of cash change?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, look Mike, we've done a couple of things. One is we've committed to this sort of consistent EBITDA and free cash flow, and we've maintained a very balanced approach and discipline to achieving that. So we have talked to you and we've recast
componenttext: Sure. I mean, look Mike, we've done a couple of things. One is we've committed to this sort of consistent EBITDA and free cash flow, and we've maintained a very balanced approach and discipline to achieving that. So we have talked to you and we've recast our numbers on the segment reporting to show you a better opportunity to see variable costs versus what I'll call fixed or semi-fixed. And we continue to do things like balance workforce to workload, continue to put things out to bid, continue to figure out better ways to operate more efficiently and perform better. So I think we feel very, very confident about the next 18 or 24 months. We feel that we are going to maintain the goals that we've set for ourselves, and we are clearly focused on the top line. And if you look at the top line results, our churn performance is some of the best we've ever had, and it's really focused now on trying to get that next new customer while we continue to try to grow the ARPU of the existing customers.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Tim Horan from Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Tim Horan from Oppenheimer.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you comment on when you think you can get back to positive revenue growth? I'm sure it's going to be tied to access line trends. And related to that, access line trends I think I'm hoping to see a little bit more of an improvement here. You think the
componenttext: Can you comment on when you think you can get back to positive revenue growth? I'm sure it's going to be tied to access line trends. And related to that, access line trends I think I'm hoping to see a little bit more of an improvement here. You think the price discounts at the low end with the prepaid guys, and we're seeing a little bit more of that yesterday, are you seeing a little bit more of an impact from those guys?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: It's Teresa. So the prepaid, no. We're not seeing an impact of that on the wireline side at all. The wireline trend is just more people just don't need that phone line in their home anymore. They're using alternatives. And then as far as the revenue, what
componenttext: It's Teresa. So the prepaid, no. We're not seeing an impact of that on the wireline side at all. The wireline trend is just more people just don't need that phone line in their home anymore. They're using alternatives. And then as far as the revenue, what we've committed to right now is to slow that decline. That's what we're focused on for this year. How the fourth quarter ends will then give us a view what is appropriate to show you into 2011.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: So I think it's an inflection point, Tim. I mean, look, we're going to hit that guidance, which I think a lot of people thought might have been a difficult thing to do. And so as we hit that guidance in the fourth quarter, the real question is sort of wha
componenttext: So I think it's an inflection point, Tim. I mean, look, we're going to hit that guidance, which I think a lot of people thought might have been a difficult thing to do. And so as we hit that guidance in the fourth quarter, the real question is sort of what are the inflection point at the bottom of the U were it turns back up? And so is it in one of the beginning quarters of 2011, or does it tail out over the longer? We're working very, very hard to see what that might be. But we feel very, very confident that we're going into the right direction, and that the inflection point is within our grasp.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and those numbers look great. And then just on the cable front, sorry to beat a dead horse here, but it could be that on the pull share cable is maybe picking up a touch-more market share and it's hard for you guys to measure that. And could you mayb
componenttext: Yes, and those numbers look great. And then just on the cable front, sorry to beat a dead horse here, but it could be that on the pull share cable is maybe picking up a touch-more market share and it's hard for you guys to measure that. And could you maybe talk about where cable is in terms of their average speeds and versus yours, and maybe what percentage of your territory do you think evacuated to DOCSIS 3.0 or well, just to give us a sense of where we're at in the process?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: So they continue to build in our territory, there's no question about that. So right now, DOCSIS 3.0 is in about 60% of our footprint. So it's significant, and it's in all of our large markets and they continue to invest there. So we continue to battle wi
componenttext: So they continue to build in our territory, there's no question about that. So right now, DOCSIS 3.0 is in about 60% of our footprint. So it's significant, and it's in all of our large markets and they continue to invest there. So we continue to battle with them everyday. We fight it out with the cable company to win the customers, and our challenge is to get the new subscribers in. So we're not just churning between each other, but as people want to come into a new speed or a new space, so we can grab that before they do.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: And you've got to think, Tim, that the majority of these customers are in sort of the sweet spot of that seven and 10 and not trying to get 100. So you got to think about the mass populace. So I think we're in good stead, and remember, the one key thing t
componenttext: And you've got to think, Tim, that the majority of these customers are in sort of the sweet spot of that seven and 10 and not trying to get 100. So you got to think about the mass populace. So I think we're in good stead, and remember, the one key thing that has delivered us results everyday is our workforce out there and the quality of the service that they are providing both on the phone and in the home, in getting people connected. And that continued to pay dividends to us, and you can see it in the reflection of our churn rates.

componenttext: Hosting, yes. Our Hosting business, I mean, we did put on a new facility back in the fourth quarter that we continue to build out and fill out, and we clearly have plans in hosting and it has been performing, continue to put on customers, et cetera. So we are working at plans to continue to try to drive that business because it has done well for us.

componenttext: Our next question comes from Peter Rhamey from BMO Capital Markets.

componenttextpreview: On the Fiber-to-the-Node footprint, it looks like the footprint has slowed in terms of coverage this quarter. I was wondering what it would take to accelerate that build, and whether you're constrained by marketing with respect to that product in the mark
componenttext: On the Fiber-to-the-Node footprint, it looks like the footprint has slowed in terms of coverage this quarter. I was wondering what it would take to accelerate that build, and whether you're constrained by marketing with respect to that product in the market?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: Peter, it didn't slow. I'm not sure what number we ended up, but we didn't slow at all actually in building the footprint. And in fact, the number of subs going into the footprint is growing, too. So we're very happy with our FTTN plans, and what drives t
componenttext: Peter, it didn't slow. I'm not sure what number we ended up, but we didn't slow at all actually in building the footprint. And in fact, the number of subs going into the footprint is growing, too. So we're very happy with our FTTN plans, and what drives that footprint is capital. So our building and how fast we do that, and we actually had a schedule and feel very confident on our commitments we've made there.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-04-2010
componenttextpreview: We've maintained a very balanced approach in the deployment of Fiber-to-the-Node. I think the good news was as a result of the Fiber-to-the-Cell, we've been much more strategic, much more integrated in getting a far better return on our capital investment
componenttext: We've maintained a very balanced approach in the deployment of Fiber-to-the-Node. I think the good news was as a result of the Fiber-to-the-Cell, we've been much more strategic, much more integrated in getting a far better return on our capital investment by doing it on an integrated basis. So it hasn't slowed at all, and we plan on meeting our targets as we set out for the beginning of the year.

And in Special Access, we're still 50-50, and we're always disappointed in Arizona response to us on that topic. But we'll keep trying.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Qwest Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Kurt Fawkes, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Qwest Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Kurt Fawkes, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you. Good morning, everybody, and welcome to our call. We're going to begin the call today with comments on the quarter from Ed Mueller, our Chairman and CEO; then Ed will be followed by Teresa Taylor, our COO, who will review segment results.
componenttext:
Okay, thank you. Good morning, everybody, and welcome to our call. We're going to begin the call today with comments on the quarter from Ed Mueller, our Chairman and CEO; then Ed will be followed by Teresa Taylor, our COO, who will review segment results. And then Joe Euteneuer, our CFO, will conclude the prepared remarks with the discussion of our consolidated financial results and outlook. We will then open it up for your questions.
I want to point you to Slide 3 and remind everyone that today's discussion contains forward-looking statements. These statements are subject to significant risks and uncertainties. These risks and uncertainties are discussed in detail in our periodic filings with the SEC, and I strongly encourage you to thoroughly review our filings. I also want to note that we do not adopt analyst estimates, nor do we necessarily commit to updating any forward-looking statements that we will be making this morning.
To supplement the reporting of our financial information, on our call today, we will be discussing certain non-GAAP financial measures, including adjusted EBITDA, adjusted free cash flow and net debt. A full reconciliation of these measures is available on our website.
Now we'll move on to Slide 4 and touch on EPS and some special items that impacted EPS in the quarter. Our reported loss per share for the quarter was $0.05, and that compares to earnings per share of $0.08 in the third quarter of 2009. The current quarter includes a $0.13 charge related to the option on the convertible notes, a $0.02 charge for severance and realignment expense and a $0.01 charge for a one-time adjustment related to USF [Universal Service Fund] fees. 
Excluding special items, earnings per share were $0.11 in the third quarter, that's a 22% improvement compared to $0.09 in the year ago quarter, as well as the second quarter of this year. Reported in adjusted earnings include dilution from non-cash pension OPEB expense. In the current quarter, the dilution was $0.01 and in the year ago period, we had an impact of $0.02. 
As a reminder, under the terms of the merger agreement with CenturyLink, we have committed to redeem our convertible debt and the value of the associated conversion rights for cash. Therefore, we previously reclassified the option component of the note from equity to a liability, which is included in accrued expense and other. The value of this liability at the end of the quarter was $349 million after initially being valued at $165 million on the date of the merger announcement. 
As a result of strong stock price appreciation during the third quarter, we reported a pre- and post-tax charge in the current period of $229 million to recognize the higher value of the option component of the convert. We have continued to see strong price appreciation in the fourth quarter. And as a result, we may have another charge when we report fourth quarter earnings. We'll be paying off the convertible principal and the value of the option in the fourth quarter.
With that, I'll now going to turn it over to Ed.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kurt. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I want to begin by saying, I'm very pleased with our execution and results we delivered in the quarter despite continued market challenges. We reported improved sequential and year-
componenttext:
Thanks, Kurt. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I want to begin by saying, I'm very pleased with our execution and results we delivered in the quarter despite continued market challenges. We reported improved sequential and year-over-year revenue trends, expanded margins and we generated strong cash flow.
In addition, we reported a number of significant achievements for the company this quarter, including record-high margins and record-low debt levels. I'm also very proud of the recognition we received during the quarter for customer service awards in both the enterprise and the wholesale units. Our performance is a strong evidence of the focus we have on our strategies to drive the top line while maintaining disciplined expense management to improving operating efficiencies.
We continue to see strong growth in our strategic revenues while we aggressively pursue fiber-based broadband services. We experienced a rebound to growth in subscriber additions, driven by demand for high-speed services, launch of a new marketing campaign and seasonal benefits. We also continued to strengthen our financial flexibility by improving the balance sheet. Our progress was recognized by a rating agency upgrade in August to investment grade. 
During the quarter, we announced plans to call our convertible debt, which totals $1.1 billion in principal and are well on the path to achieve our stated debt reduction goals. In addition, I'm very happy with the progress we're making toward the completion of our merger with CenturyLink. The senior leadership team for the combined company has been named. The second-tier team was also recently announced. Activities are well underway in the planning process for the integration of the two companies. We have reached several key milestones in the approval process, including overwhelming support from both company shareholders.
Last month, our unions agreed that the merger is in the public interest, and withdrew all opposition. We continue to make progress with various agencies and commissions required to review the transaction. To date, we've received approvals in 12 states. In addition to the SEC, we have 10 states remaining to review and approve the transaction.
To sum up, we've had a solid execution in the quarter, and we're well on the path to achieve our stated objectives. We are confident we will continue to execute for the remainder of the year. As a result, we are raising our revenue, EBITDA and free cash flow outlook to the top end of the 2010 guidance. Joe will provide you with the details.
We continue to expect our merger with CenturyLink to close in the first half of 2011. We're excited about the prospects that will rise from the combination of our two companies. Our respective shareholders have already benefited from the operating and stock performance of the two companies since our announcement.
Looking ahead, Qwest shareholders will benefit from significant synergies, a nearly 50% increase in dividends from today's level, accelerated deleveraging of balance sheet, a strong management team and a talented employee base. I remain firmly convinced this transaction will further bolster our results and drive superior shareholder value. 
Now I'll hand it off to Teresa, who will discuss our business unit performance.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ed, and good morning, everyone. I'm very pleased with our performance in the third quarter. Under challenging market conditions, we continue to deliver on our goal to improve the top line trend. In the quarter, all three segments again reported
componenttext:
Thank you, Ed, and good morning, everyone. I'm very pleased with our performance in the third quarter. Under challenging market conditions, we continue to deliver on our goal to improve the top line trend. In the quarter, all three segments again reported improved revenue trends on both the sequential and year-over-year basis. We achieved solid subscriber additions on our fiber-to-the-node network, maintained steady performance in Business Markets and improved top line trends in Wholesale.
Solid customer demand for strategic products continue to provide an increasing revenue contribution in each of the units. Total strategic revenue grew 8% compared to the year ago quarter, driven by 24% growth in enterprise IP services and growth in residential fiber-based services. This compares to 6% year-over-year growth in the second quarter.
Legacy revenue losses improved substantially in the quarter as well. Sequentially, legacy revenue was down 1% in the quarter compared with 4% last quarter.
We also continue to maintain a disciplined focus on the bottom line. Adjusted EBITDA and operating income both increased nearly 3% compared to the prior year. And we'll begin the discussion of our individual business unit performance with the Business Market segment on Slide 9. 
Business Markets reported third quarter revenues of $1 million. This is flat with the prior year quarter and up 2% sequentially. Recurring revenue held steady in the quarter, both annually and sequentially. Similar to the 2009 trend, we did see sequential growth in data integration in the quarter.
In the Enterprise space, we continue to see encouraging signs in customer activity and steadily increasing sales level. This segment also benefited from improved sales rep productivity and strong customer retention. Strategic revenue in Business Markets now exceed the legacy revenue for the first time since we began reporting this mix. Strategic revenues increased 9% compared to the third quarter of 2009. This was driven by a continued strong demand for our MPLS [Multiprotocol Label Switching] and high-capacity IP services. The growth in strategic revenues was offset by a 7% decline in legacy data and local voice services.
During the quarter, Qwest was a recipient for the third consecutive year of the prestigious Nemertes PilotHouse Award and cited top provider of carrier Internet services. Qwest outperformed every other market challenger in most categories, achieving top ratings for customer service and overall value. 
In the third quarter, Business Markets segment income of $415 million increased 4% year-over-year and 7% from the second quarter. The improvement in the quarter is driven by improved sales productivity and a one-time legal settlement in the second quarter. Segment margin for the quarter expanded 140 basis points annually and 190 basis points sequentially to 40.7%.
In summary, we are encouraged by the increased activity and positive new sales momentum. We continue to expect revenues will start to pick up as economic conditions improve. 
Results for our Wholesale segment are summarized on Slide 10. During the quarter, our Wholesale unit also received strong honors. For the 10th consecutive time, Atlantic-ACM recognized Qwest for best-in-class customer service, provisioning, network performance and billing in the ILEC [Incumbent Local Exchange Carrier] category, as well as best in class across all carriers for data value.
For the first time in more than three years, Wholesale revenue held steady sequentially. Wholesale segment revenue for the quarter totaled $661 million, a decline of 8% year-over-year. Wholesale is benefiting from an improved strategic product mix that now represents 49% of total segment revenue. 
Strategic revenues grew 6% compared with the prior year and 2% in the second quarter. This growth is being offset by declines in legacy voice services. However, legacy voice losses improved in the quarter as we saw less intense pressure in long distance and grooming efforts. Legacy revenues were down 1% sequentially, which is a marked improvement from the 8% decline last quarter. The improved mix and demand for strategic services resulted in a 480 basis point increase in margin to 67.8%. 
Our Wholesale group continues to make significant progress in delivering fiber-based backhaul services for wireless carriers. We have completed construction and began billing on fiber services for more than 1,000 sites, and we continue to expect this to grow to about 2,000 sites by year end. 
As a reminder, we will have modest revenues from this program this year, and this initiative is expected to help mitigate Wholesale revenue pressures over the next several quarters. For the long run, this provides an avenue for strategic revenue growth. 
Now let's turn to Mass Markets results on Slide 11. This unit achieved its fourth consecutive quarter of improved year-over-year revenue trend. Excluding the impact of the wireless reseller transition that was completed last year, Mass Markets revenue for the quarter declined 3% year-over-year and held steady sequentially. Within Mass Markets, strategic revenues increased to 33% of segment revenue compared to 28% a year ago. Strategic revenues improved 10% year-over-year while legacy revenue declined 9% due to continued pressure on traditional local voice services.
Consumer voice revenue now represents less than 20% of total consolidated revenue. In the third quarter, the company's High-Speed Internet marketing campaign achieved good success. We also experienced a stronger contribution from our Small business unit, which reported improved revenue trends, driven mainly by pricing action. As a reminder, Small Business represents about 20% of Mass Markets' total revenue or a little more than $900 million annually. 
In the quarter, total expenses declined 9% in the third quarter of 2009 due to fewer employees, reduced wireless costs and lower sales and marketing expense. Mass Markets segment income of $617 million declined 1% year-over-year and sequentially. Segment margin of 53% improved to 190 basis points compared to the third quarter last year and declined 50 basis points sequentially. 
Our quarterly subscribers results are shown on Slide 12. The number and rate of consumer and small business voice access line loss in the quarter improved on a year-over-year basis and held steady with the second quarter. We continue to grow the revenues from customers we retained. Consumer ARPU improved during the quarter to $65, up 10% compared to the third quarter of 2009. The improvement was driven by growth in broadband, wireless and video users. And a higher speed mix was in our broadband customer base. 
We continue to expand our fiber-to-the-node footprint. Services are now available to approximately 4.5 million residential households. In the quarter, we added 92,000 new subscribers on fiber services. And we now serve 620,000 broadband fiber subscribers. At the end of the quarter in 2009, fiber-based customers numbered just 330,000. Fiber-to-the-node additions in the quarter were offset by a 52,000 subscriber decline in traditional ATM-based DSL. 
As I mentioned, we are pleased with the response we are seeing from the launch of our new High-Speed Internet promotional campaign during the quarter. The campaign is focused on full Internet service and includes wireless, security, and technical support. Following the launch, call volumes of orders increased measurably. We also saw increased activity in online ordering through qwest.com. And finally, we benefited sequentially from positive seasonal influences in the third quarter.
In the quarter, video subscribers increased 12,000 to 963,000. This growth was also aided by seasonal influences such as the NFL package. Our Wireless business continued to have a strong performance in the quarter and now exceeds 1 million subscribers. The increase in number of Qwest-billed Verizon Wireless users by 62,000. 
In closing, I'm pleased with the momentum we saw in the third quarter. We delivered solid operational results and improved top line performance across all segments. We achieved this while maintaining a sharp focus on expense management and disciplined investments. I am confident we will continue to deliver solid results as we complete the remainder of the year. I look forward to updating you on our next call.
And now I'll turn it over to Joe.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Teresa. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. In third quarter, we again delivered another quarter of strong operating and financial performance. We met our goal of reducing the rate of loss of revenue to a low-single digi
componenttext:
Thank you, Teresa. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. In third quarter, we again delivered another quarter of strong operating and financial performance. We met our goal of reducing the rate of loss of revenue to a low-single digit rate of decline, a quarter ahead of schedule.
Adjusted EBITDA margin expanded to 38.2%. This represents another record margin for Qwest. We generated strong free cash flow in the quarter, and we continued to improve our financial flexibility.
Now let's start by turning to the income statement on Slide 14. In the third quarter, consolidated revenues of $2.9 billion were flat sequentially for the first time in eight quarters and declined 4% compared to the prior year. Excluding the impact of the wireless transition, revenues only declined 3% versus the prior year. As Teresa noted, the improved year-over-year comparison is due to stronger results in each segment. Consolidated strategic services revenue grew 8% compared to the year ago quarter. Strategic services are a larger contributor in each of our segments, mainly due to higher demand for fiber-based broadband services and IP solutions. In the quarter, strategic revenue grew to 39% of total revenue from 34% a year ago.
In addition to revenue performance improvements, we continue to maintain a disciplined focus on the bottom line. Total operating expenses improved 5% from the prior year. The improved operating costs are driven by our ongoing efforts to increase operating efficiency and productivity through balancing work force to workload, process improvements and reductions in network facility costs. 
Operating expenses increased 1% sequentially. The increase in the quarter was primarily due to realignment and severance cost of $51 million and a one-time adjustment related to USF fees of $15 million. Without the special items, expenses improved 1% sequentially. Adjusted EBITDA of $1.1 billion for the quarter increased 3% from the year ago period and nearly 3% from the second quarter. Adjusted EBITDA margin of 38.2% expanded 240 basis points year-over-year and 90 basis points sequentially.
Moving on to Slide 15. We continued to strengthen the balance sheet in the third quarter and improve our financial flexibility. We ended the third quarter with net debt of $11 billion. This is a decline of $1 billion from the third quarter of 2009 and nearly $300 million from the second quarter. Cash increased in the quarter to $2 billion. Net debt to annualized adjusted EBITDA was 2.5x at the end of the quarter. This is another significant achievement and the lowest leverage ratio for the company since 1999.
Last month, we announced plans to redeem all of the company's convertible notes. Approximately $1.1 billion in principal is outstanding after tendering for $147 million in August. We are well down the path to achieve our $3.5 billion stated debt reduction by February 2011.
Now let's turn to Slide 16, which shows the details on adjusted free cash flow and capital expenditures. An improved revenue mix and continued diligence on expenses produced strong adjusted free cash flow of $554 million in the quarter. We continue to focus our capital spending on funding key fiber-based broadband initiatives. Capital expenditures were $373 million compared with $340 million in the third quarter of 2009 and $330 million last quarter.
In the quarter, our DSO of 38.6 days improved one full day compared to the year ago period. Our collections staff continues to execute very well. We achieved a 14% year-over-year improvement in bad debt expense, and bad debt is now less than 1% of total revenue.
Before I close with the discussion of our outlook, I would like to update you on our returns on invested capital on Slide 17. Cumulative return on invested capital for the last 12 months improved 60 basis points compared to the previous 12 months. This reflects steady net operating profit after tax while our asset base declined. In fact, net PP&E is down $570 million year-over-year. With our current returns, we are earning above our internal estimate for our cost of capital and as you can see, the gap is improving.
Now let's turn to our guidance on Slide 18. For the near term, we continue to see a stable outlook for Business Markets. We expect to see enterprise revenue improve as the economy recovers. In Wholesale, we are pleased with the steady top line trends in the quarter. Our goal is to continue to stabilize the top line sequentially and to report improving year-over-year rates of decline. In the fourth quarter, we expect Mass Markets to report a low-single digit sequential decline. As Ed mentioned, we are raising our outlook overall for the year. We now expect consolidated revenues to decline at a low-single digit annual rate of decline in the fourth quarter, similar to what we achieved this quarter, one quarter ahead of schedule.
We also expect adjusted EBITDA to be at the high end of the range for the year of approximately $4.4 billion. We continue to expect capital investment of approximately $1.7 billion, with about $115 million of the investment to be financed by leasing. Our capital spending program reflects our focus on Fiber-to-the-Cell opportunities and our continued investment in fiber-to-the-node on an integrated basis.
Free cash flow for the year is now expected to be $1.7 billion to $1.8 billion with the benefit of the capital leasing activities. Without the benefit of the capital leasing activities, free cash flow is expected to be in the range of $1.6 billion to $1.7 billion.
As we stated last quarter regarding the pension, we do not expect to make any funding contributions to the pension plan in 2010. And our current expectation is that we will not have any required funding in 2011 as well.
Regarding taxes, we continue to expect to pay cash taxes of approximately 2% this year. As I mentioned, we will redeem our convert in the fourth quarter. In addition, we plan to make a cash payment for the premium over the option strike price. The amount of this payment will depend on the future stock price. If you were to assume all holders convert with a stock price of $6.67, which was yesterday's close, this value would be approximately $450 million.
Returning value to shareholders remains a priority, and we made a dividend payment of $0.08 per share or $139 million in the third quarter. And on October 21, the company announced an $0.08 per share dividend to be paid in the fourth quarter as well.
As we noted in the CenturyLink merger announcement, it is our current expectation that we will continue to pay a quarterly dividend of $0.08 per share through the close of the transaction. The merger agreement requires the company to coordinate with CenturyLink on dividend dates. As a result, the timing of future dividends may deviate from past dates due to this requirement.
In closing, I'd like to reiterate how pleased I am with our results this quarter. We are confident that we will continue this momentum as we close out the year. 
With that, I'll turn the call back over to the operator, and we'll open the lines for questions.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010

Do think in some respects this could be eating into that? Or do you still see a path to meet or exceed the synergies that you've laid out at the time of announcing the merger?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And just out of curiosity, I think, if you go back a year ago, the question was how long can you keep EBITDA at or above the current levels while seeing some of the erosion in revenue. And clearly this year you've done a very good job of managing that. Se
componenttext: And just out of curiosity, I think, if you go back a year ago, the question was how long can you keep EBITDA at or above the current levels while seeing some of the erosion in revenue. And clearly this year you've done a very good job of managing that. Separate from the merger synergies, do you still see Qwest as having more legs in terms of being able to minimize the EBITDA impact relative to the rate of revenue erosion? Is there a ratio or some way the investors should be thinking about that relationship?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010

componenttext: Michael, as we're seeing good results on the revenue, that's relieving the pressure on the expense side. So we feel confident about our EBITDA objectives, and it's playing out just the way we wanted it to. So as the revenue is improving, that's giving us the room on the expense side.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: First, Joe, could you kind of call this quarter the inflection quarter for revenue? Can we start looking at this initial kind of step-by-step growth in the sequential revenue trends and kind of extrapolate them? And if there are areas where we can't, coul
componenttext: First, Joe, could you kind of call this quarter the inflection quarter for revenue? Can we start looking at this initial kind of step-by-step growth in the sequential revenue trends and kind of extrapolate them? And if there are areas where we can't, could you kind of walk us through what we should be expecting as we kind of move in the right direction revenue-wise? And second, I think you guys have kind of continued to mention that you don't have a cash contribution requirement for pensions this and next year. But I think you guys do end up showing up on a lot of screens in terms of pension liabilities relative to earnings power and market cap. So could you kind of give us a little color on where you think the year-over-year earnings impact of kind of the interest rate environment would be on the earnings contribution net income for the income statement?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me start with your first one. So if you remember back in February when we talked, we were talking about continuing to get down to this low-single digit rate of decline of revenue to at some point over the next coming year trying to hit that inflection
componenttext: Let me start with your first one. So if you remember back in February when we talked, we were talking about continuing to get down to this low-single digit rate of decline of revenue to at some point over the next coming year trying to hit that inflection point. To hit that inflection point, you do need the economy to improve and the ability of business markets to get better growth than what we've been achieving to date. So we're close to the infection point. We'll continue to drive and reduce that rate of decline, but we'd love to see some help from the economy. In regards to the cash pension, you're exactly right. We have no cash funding requirements for '10 or '11. Our liability, you can see stated in the financial statements, if you were to cut things off today, and we valued everything, you would probably have a bookkeeping charge going into 2011, an increase. But because you're only measuring it once a year, you just sort of look at what happens to the marketplace by year end. And your last question, what was the last question, Dave?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, Joe, just kind of taking that pension expense issue a little further. With interest rates lower, the liabilities are higher, the expenses are going to be higher, your debt portfolio presumably is a little bit more valuable today than it was. If y
componenttext: I guess, Joe, just kind of taking that pension expense issue a little further. With interest rates lower, the liabilities are higher, the expenses are going to be higher, your debt portfolio presumably is a little bit more valuable today than it was. If you net those things out, what's the earnings impact year-over-year as you look at the pension today?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010

componenttext: So for next year, you would have an increase of pension expense. We haven't come up -- we won't be able to measure that until year end when we get the final numbers. But based on where things are today, we would think that there would be somewhat of an increase.

componenttextpreview: And I just want to continue on that revenue theme, and just take it a little bit further down. Enterprise remains stable. I was intrigued to hear that SMB segment was beginning to show some momentum, which is maybe a leading indicator for what's going to
componenttext: And I just want to continue on that revenue theme, and just take it a little bit further down. Enterprise remains stable. I was intrigued to hear that SMB segment was beginning to show some momentum, which is maybe a leading indicator for what's going to happen in enterprise. Any color on that would be very useful, whether its regional base or is it something you've seen through all your markets. Second question on wholesale, I guess, I read into the commentary by Joe is that the grooming, the pricing increases that you've implemented in wholesale to get your customer to sell select, that phase is largely over and now the top line should remain relatively stable. Is that how shall I read your comments there? And what are the implications for margins? I assume that it means that wholesale margins will remain stable going forward as well.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Peter, this is Teresa. In the small business market, a lot of our movements this last quarter was in pricing and bundling activity. So I'm not really in a place to say that small business is turning around. I think this was some activity that we caused in
componenttext: Peter, this is Teresa. In the small business market, a lot of our movements this last quarter was in pricing and bundling activity. So I'm not really in a place to say that small business is turning around. I think this was some activity that we caused in the marketplace in the way we're repackaging and pricing and bundling. So we still need the economy. I mean, the bankruptcies are still high in small business, that's still the really rough market and highly competitive.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We're always looking maybe ahead. But did your competitors follow suite on the price increases by any chance?
componenttext: We're always looking maybe ahead. But did your competitors follow suite on the price increases by any chance?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I would say we were probably catching up with them, because they were ahead of us. And like I said, the small business market is hypercompetitive with resellers and class and the cable companies. And so if anything, we were following behind them. They're
componenttext: I would say we were probably catching up with them, because they were ahead of us. And like I said, the small business market is hypercompetitive with resellers and class and the cable companies. And so if anything, we were following behind them. They're ahead of us. And then on wholesale, you are correct. We are through the phase where we were raising prices for long distance and having the cell selection process. But wholesale is still challenging and that local access is always a delicate area. And we are getting good news in the private line area where the grooming had stopped a little bit. And of course Fiber-to-the-Cell is giving us a way to offset some of those declines. So we see promising signs at wholesale that it seems to be stabilizing out, but that local access site is still very tentative in how that market operates quarter-to-quarter.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: On that local access site, is that getting worse in terms of momentum?
componenttext: On that local access site, is that getting worse in terms of momentum?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Right now, it's actually stabilized. But I've seen this a number of years. It goes up and down. It's volatile.
componenttext: Right now, it's actually stabilized. But I've seen this a number of years. It goes up and down. It's volatile.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: It's hard to predict. And the good news for the wholesale group is the fact that the Fiber-to-the-Cell continues to be a pretty vibrant environment. We have construction scheduled now well into 2011. So that is the growth revenue coming into the segment t
componenttext: It's hard to predict. And the good news for the wholesale group is the fact that the Fiber-to-the-Cell continues to be a pretty vibrant environment. We have construction scheduled now well into 2011. So that is the growth revenue coming into the segment that will help offset some of these potential declines that we've gotten a lot out of the system, but we can't be positive that it's 100% done.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll now hear from Scott Goldman with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll now hear from Scott Goldman with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to hit on EBITDA. So you guys raised guidance towards the top end of prior. If we look at that revised guidance when you guys are done year-to-date, would seem to imply about a 5% sequential drop to reach your target in the fourth quarter. So I'm
componenttext: I wanted to hit on EBITDA. So you guys raised guidance towards the top end of prior. If we look at that revised guidance when you guys are done year-to-date, would seem to imply about a 5% sequential drop to reach your target in the fourth quarter. So I'm just wondering if there's something we should be thinking about in 4Q, maybe some of the seasonal costs that you expect in 3Q kind of pushing to 4Q. Or what might cause a drop in 4Q EBITDA? And then secondly on fiber-to-the-node, it looks like you've accelerated the number of incrementals homes in the quarter, now tracking above the 1 million for the year, which is kind of a target you've thrown out there before. And given the results that you guys have put up, is this something we should expect maybe an accelerated pace of build-outs heading into 2011?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess on your last question, remember, we are very focused on the integrated build and the fact that we've had such vibrant build on Fiber-to-the-Cell. We look to what additional homes we can get, et cetera. So we're far more cost effective in the deplo
componenttext: I guess on your last question, remember, we are very focused on the integrated build and the fact that we've had such vibrant build on Fiber-to-the-Cell. We look to what additional homes we can get, et cetera. So we're far more cost effective in the deployment of our capital than we've ever been before, and the good news is we did get a few extra homes out of it. But we will continue our disciplined approach of approximately 1 million homes a year and stay on that schedule. So if we are able to get a few more homes as a result of the employment of Fiber-to-the-Cell, we'll take advantage of it. In regards to your EBITDA question, remember, going into the fourth quarter, we have sort of the seasonal decline. As you're coming off, Business Markets sales start closing up for the November and December point. Some of the seasonal expenses we get out of our repairs and maintenance maybe pushing a little bit into the fourth quarter. But overall, we are still very much on track to deliver the high end of that range and have a consistent performance without any bumps in the night.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: One quick follow up on the fiber-to-the-node. Can you just tell us again maybe how much of the DSO losses are really just migrations over to the fiber-to-the-node platform?
componenttext: One quick follow up on the fiber-to-the-node. Can you just tell us again maybe how much of the DSO losses are really just migrations over to the fiber-to-the-node platform?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, what we're saying is we're not going to have new adds in. For the losses, I mean, the churn rate is good actually, one of the best we've ever had. So we're not going to grow back in. So what's happening is just like in the new sales, and that's wha
componenttext: Scott, what we're saying is we're not going to have new adds in. For the losses, I mean, the churn rate is good actually, one of the best we've ever had. So we're not going to grow back in. So what's happening is just like in the new sales, and that's what we're focused on this quarter.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: But those are not a part of those losses that are going over to the fiber-to-the-node?
componenttext: But those are not a part of those losses that are going over to the fiber-to-the-node?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, but that's not the big problem. What we worry about here is not that, because we're making it happen, right? We're encouraging our customers to do that. But we're just not getting new adds into that portfolio. And that's what we're focused on
componenttext: Absolutely, but that's not the big problem. What we worry about here is not that, because we're making it happen, right? We're encouraging our customers to do that. But we're just not getting new adds into that portfolio. And that's what we're focused on this quarter.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll now hear from Tim Horan with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: We'll now hear from Tim Horan with Oppenheimer.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Sorry to beat a dead horse here on revenue. but it's entrusting to see the legacy revenues a lot better. I know one quarter doesn't make a trend. But it's kind of interesting, access line buyings were a little weak, and it sounds like on the small busines
componenttext: Sorry to beat a dead horse here on revenue. but it's entrusting to see the legacy revenues a lot better. I know one quarter doesn't make a trend. But it's kind of interesting, access line buyings were a little weak, and it sounds like on the small business, you've been a little more aggressive on pricing. So is it a pricing issue or a volume issue or we just hit a point on legacy volumes on kind of -- you mentioned private lines that may be worsening some stability. Just some thoughts on that because it's clearly been the legacy revenues have been obviously the problem for you guys and for the whole industry.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me start by, I think, Tim, execution across the board has been very good for us. We've talked historically about focusing on retention, focusing on how do we grow our ARPU and then trying to get that next new customer. And I think our churn rates, our
componenttext: Let me start by, I think, Tim, execution across the board has been very good for us. We've talked historically about focusing on retention, focusing on how do we grow our ARPU and then trying to get that next new customer. And I think our churn rates, our bad debt rates, our ability to grow ARPU has been better than ever and very, very consistent in our execution on that. And we continue to fight each day to gain that next new customer, and we've been doing it on a far more integrated basis than we ever have before because we would like to hit that inflection point at some point out in the future. So I think it's really execution in all of the segments, focusing on those three things in that order.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I'd probably just add a little color per five segment so we'd have to look differently to the group. So in the consumer space, we are seeing that slow down. We obviously are very focused on premium high-speed Internet in there, and it does appear that thi
componenttext: I'd probably just add a little color per five segment so we'd have to look differently to the group. So in the consumer space, we are seeing that slow down. We obviously are very focused on premium high-speed Internet in there, and it does appear that this just slowed a bit, and also we saw the bottom because I never know where the bottom is, but it definitely come into play. In the small business area, we have mentioned earlier, still highly competitive. We've had the opportunity to raise prices in some areas and lower prices in others through bundling. And then in the wholesale space, we're really just -- that grooming thing seems to slowdown. We've reached the point where all the carriers are where they want to be on their private line. It would be great if AT&T and Verizon had an uptick in their enterprise sales because that would benefit us on the wholesale side. It just seems stable. I would use that word right now on the legacy side. In the BMG space, we are aggressively trying to move our customers into the IP space. So we encourage them and offer them incentives to get away from legacy products and move into strategic area.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the fiber side, the fiber-to-the-node, what are the customers' experience in actual speed when they have fiber-to-the-node versus your legacy kind of DSL and how do you think that compares to cable and maybe the same thing in ARPU, maybe you c
componenttext: And then on the fiber side, the fiber-to-the-node, what are the customers' experience in actual speed when they have fiber-to-the-node versus your legacy kind of DSL and how do you think that compares to cable and maybe the same thing in ARPU, maybe you can talk about the difference in those customers.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: So fiber-to-the-node to us is seven megabits and higher. And by higher, I mean up to 40. So that's where we stop at this point. Interesting enough that we had a promotion in the market your customer could pick their seat and say where they want to be and
componenttext: So fiber-to-the-node to us is seven megabits and higher. And by higher, I mean up to 40. So that's where we stop at this point. Interesting enough that we had a promotion in the market your customer could pick their seat and say where they want to be and they did not pick the high-speed. They picked around 12, maybe 20. So it was an interesting phenomenon there, what customers will actually pay for and what they are willing to absorb on a monthly bill. But in general, the cable companies do have more speed. We've been very successful this last quarter with the promotion and with a new campaign, but it's not about speed, it's about technical support and security and wireless access and that seems to be doing very well in the marketplace with our customers.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010

componenttext: We continue to apply at 40 megs at the same close we did 20 megs last year.

componenttext: And how is your ARPU for the customers legacy versus fiber-to-the-node? Is there much difference?

componenttext: Fiber-to-the-node is significantly higher. The legacy is the ATM speed. So that's very low monthly rate, where when you get up into the fiber, you can go as high as $100 a month. It can go all the way up.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, I was going to -- on that same line of thinking, Teresa, you talked about less port outs. Are we seeing less wireless substitution? Are we seeing less competition from the cable VoIPs [Voice over IP]? Is there a less competitive environment? Do
componenttext: Actually, I was going to -- on that same line of thinking, Teresa, you talked about less port outs. Are we seeing less wireless substitution? Are we seeing less competition from the cable VoIPs [Voice over IP]? Is there a less competitive environment? Do you think that we've sort of hit the point where there's less to be taken? I just wondered if you could just talk a little bit about what the competitive dynamics are. We've also seen some slightly better numbers than some of the other goals, and I'm wondering if the cable has laid off the competitive pedals, so to speak, for the quarter. Could we see that swing back?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I wish there were layoffs. They're right in there. They've not changed at all. They're extremely aggressive and if anything, maybe, Chris, we're trading customers. That's probably what's happening a lot, and we continue to look for expansion to bring in n
componenttext: I wish there were layoffs. They're right in there. They've not changed at all. They're extremely aggressive and if anything, maybe, Chris, we're trading customers. That's probably what's happening a lot, and we continue to look for expansion to bring in new customers. I mean, it's still a question are -- a lot of people, believe it or not, are still at low speed and maybe even dialing up in some rural areas. But we're trying to bring customers into the higher speeds, and I think our current results reflect that we're doing okay with that right now. But the cable companies are extremely competitive. They are not letting up at all.

componenttext: On the high-speed, we do not see wireless interfering with that. But we do see that customers will disconnect their voice landlines for wireless substitutions, that continues to increase. But we also see something that as people are disconnecting their voice lines and going nowhere. I mean, maybe they had wireless, but they're not going to VoIP, I guess, is just another way to look at that. And we don't see a lot of activities there. Either they're disconnecting completely, or they're disconnecting and going to wireless.

componenttext: Simon, this is Ed. The timeline, it's kind of like we've laid out before. componenttext: And Simon, on our CyberCenter, we're happy with the results. I would call it stable. The revenue is slightly up. It gave us opportunities to open new centers, but I don't think we're quite ready to announce that yet. But we're always looking for ability to expand that footprint.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you could talk qualitatively about through the buckets of cost reduction you have. What areas are pretty well tapped out? What areas still have room to go, and also what sort of cost reduction areas are going to be dependent to a degree o
componenttext: I'm wondering if you could talk qualitatively about through the buckets of cost reduction you have. What areas are pretty well tapped out? What areas still have room to go, and also what sort of cost reduction areas are going to be dependent to a degree on continuing revenue declines? And are there areas where you can continue to take out absolute cost dollars even if revenue starts to recover?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: James, I think we continue to say that we go across the board. It's not any one point in time that we pick something to take cost out. It's an effort that everybody in the company looks at everyday. So whether it's taking reducing the rates on variable co
componenttext: James, I think we continue to say that we go across the board. It's not any one point in time that we pick something to take cost out. It's an effort that everybody in the company looks at everyday. So whether it's taking reducing the rates on variable costs to improve gross margins, whether it's the efficiencies we do to drive better fixed costs or the rates of what we pay for fixed costs or the continuing to balance work force to workload, those are things that is part of our D&A. Everyday, Teresa and I, along with the entire management team, we focus on that and look out into the future. So it's not about just focusing on what's happening in the coming quarter, but it's about our plan to anticipate where the business is going out into the future and making sure that we're well ahead of the curve and make sure that we can maintain that consistent EBITDA.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: James, like I was saying earlier, as we get some revenue relief, if you want to think of it that way, the expense side does not have to be reduced as much in order for us to hold where we want to be. And that's why we're very happy this quarter with how t
componenttext: James, like I was saying earlier, as we get some revenue relief, if you want to think of it that way, the expense side does not have to be reduced as much in order for us to hold where we want to be. And that's why we're very happy this quarter with how the revenue is starting to slow down in that rate of decline.

componenttext: Can you just talk about your Fiber-to-the-Cell business to sort of capacity volume or port capacity that is currently being taken and if you assume I guess this will be the oldest sites or earlier sites whether you're seeing customers going back and increasing capacity commitments and how these trends are playing out. componenttext: In the Fiber-to-the-Cell, yes, the capacity continues to grow. In some cases, customers who came in early are expanding when they're already installed. And others are coming in higher. So it's been phenomenal. Actually, it's been amazing for me, and it's driven by all the wireless devices that are coming out and all the activity that you see in the market. But it's increasing quickly as far as the speed that everybody needs. On the small business side, it was a combination. We did raise prices on some legacy products, and we declined and bundled some of our new services. So the combination of both, up and down, which netted enough as you could see in the results there.

componenttext: Yes, so we're pushing -- I really probably can't answer that right now because as you look at the cell sites, there's copper going in there right now that the customer has and we moved some of that out and put the fiber in and looking for it to net some growth in the years to come.
