headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Qwest third quarter 2010 earnings results conference call. Todays conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Kurt Fawkes, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations.
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Qwest third quarter 2010 earnings results conference call. Todays conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Kurt Fawkes, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you. Good morning everybody and welcome to our call. Were going to begin the call today with comments on the quarter from Ed Mueller, our Chairman and CEO, and then Ed will be followed by Teresa Taylor, our COO, who will review segment resu
componenttext:
Okay, thank you. Good morning everybody and welcome to our call. Were going to begin the call today with comments on the quarter from Ed Mueller, our Chairman and CEO, and then Ed will be followed by Teresa Taylor, our COO, who will review segment results, and then Joe Euteneuer, our CFO, will conclude the prepared remarks with a discussion of our consolidated financial results and outlook. Well then open it up for your questions.
I want to point you to slide #3 and remind everyone that todays discussion contains forward-looking statements. These statements are subject to significant risk and uncertainties. These risks and uncertainties are discussed in detail in our periodic filings with the SEC, and I strongly encourage you to thoroughly review our filings.
I also want to note that we do not adopt analyst estimates, nor do we necessarily commit to updating any forward-looking statements that we will be making this morning.
To supplement the reporting of our financial information, on our call today, we will be discussing certain non-GAAP financial measures, including adjusted EBITDA, adjusted free cash flow and net debt. A full reconciliation of these measures is available on our Web site.
Now, well move on to slide four and touch on EPS and some special items that impacted EPS in the quarter. Our reported loss per share for the quarter was $0.05 and that compares to earnings per share of $0.08 in the third quarter of 2009. The current quarter includes a $0.13 charge related to the option on the convertible notes, a $0.02 charge for severance and realignment expense and $0.01 charge for one-time adjustment related to USF fees.
Excluding special items, earnings per share were $0.11 in the third quarter and thats a 22% improvement compared to $0.09 in the year ago quarter as well as the second quarter of this year. Reported and adjusted earnings include dilution from non-cash pension and OPEB expense. In the current quarter, the dilution was $0.01, and in the year-ago period, we had an impact of $0.02.
As a reminder, under the terms of the merger agreement with CenturyLink, we have committed to redeem our convertible debt and the value of the associated conversion rights for cash.
Therefore, we previously reclassified the option component of the note from equity to a liability, which is included in accrued expenses and other. The value of this liability at the end of the quarter was $349 million after initially being valued at $165 million on the date of the merger announcement.
As a result of strong stock price appreciation during the third quarter, we reported a pre and post-tax charge in the current period of $229 million to recognize the higher value of the option component of the convert.
We continue to see strong price appreciation in the fourth quarter, and as a result, we may have another charge when we report fourth quarter earnings. Well be paying-off the convertible principal and to value of the option in the fourth quarter.
With that, Im now going to turn it over to Ed.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kurt. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I want to begin by saying Im very pleased with our execution and the results we delivered in the quarter despite continued market challenges.We reported improved sequential and
componenttext:
Thanks, Kurt. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I want to begin by saying Im very pleased with our execution and the results we delivered in the quarter despite continued market challenges.
We reported improved sequential and year-over-year revenue trends, expanded margins, and we generated strong cash flow. In addition, we reported a number of significant achievements for the company this quarter, including record high margins and record low debt levels.
Im also very proud of the recognition we received during the quarter for customer service awards in both the enterprise and wholesale units. Our performance is strong evidence of the focus we have on our strategies to drive the top line while maintaining disciplined expense management to improving operating efficiencies.
We continue to see strong growth in our strategic revenues while we aggressively pursue fiber-based broadband services. We experienced a rebound to growth and subscriber additions, driven by demand for high-speed services, the launch of a new marketing campaign and seasonal benefits.
We also continue to strengthen our financial flexibility by improving the balance sheet. Our progress was recognized by a rating agency upgrade in August to investment grade. During the quarter, we announced plans to call our convertible debt which totals $1.1 billion in principal and are well on the path to achieve our stated debt reduction goals.
In addition, Im very happy with the progress we are making towards the completion of our merger with CenturyLink. The senior leadership team for the combined company has been named. The second tier team was also recently announced. Activities are well underway in the planning process for the integration of the two companies.
We have reached several key milestones in the approval process, including overwhelming support from both companies shareholders. Last month, our unions agreed that the merger is in the public interest and withdrew all opposition.
We continue to make progress with various agencies and commissions required to review the transaction. To-date, we have received approvals in 12 states. In addition to the SEC, we have 10 states remaining to review and to approve the transaction.
To sum up, we have had a solid execution in the quarter and we are well on the path to achieve our stated objectives. We are confident we will continue to execute for the remainder of the year. As a result, we are raising our revenue EBITDA and free cash flow outlook at the top end of the 2010 guidance. Joe, will provide you with the details.
We continue to expect our merger with CenturyLink to close in the first half of 2011. We are excited about the prospects that will rise from the combination of our two companies. Our respected shareholders have already benefited from the operating and stock performance of the two companies since our announcement.
Looking ahead, Qwest shareholders will benefit from significant synergies and nearly 50% increase in dividends from todays level accelerated deleveraging the balance sheet, a strong management team and a talented employee base. I remain firmly convinced this transaction will further bolster our results and drive superior shareholder value.
Now, Ill hand it off to Teresa, who will discuss our business unit performance.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ed, and good morning, everyone. I am very pleased with our performance in the third quarter. Under challenging market conditions, we continue to deliver on our goal to improve the top line trend. In the quarter, all three segments again reporte
componenttext:
Thank you, Ed, and good morning, everyone. I am very pleased with our performance in the third quarter. Under challenging market conditions, we continue to deliver on our goal to improve the top line trend. In the quarter, all three segments again reported improved revenue trends on both the sequential and year-over-year bases.
We achieved solid subscriber additions on our fiber-to-the-node network, maintained steady performance in business markets and improved top line trends in Wholesale.
Solid customer demand for strategic products continued to provide an increasing revenue contribution in each of the unit. Total strategic revenue grew 8% compared to the year ago quarter, driven by 24% growth in enterprise IP services and growth in residential fiber-based services. This compares to 6% year-over-year growth in the second quarter.
Legacy revenue losses improved substantially in the quarter as well. Sequentially, legacy revenue was down 1% in the quarter compared with 4% last quarter. We also continue to maintain a disciplined focus on the bottom line. Adjusted EBITDA and operating income both increased nearly 3% compared to the prior year.
I will begin the discussion of our individual business unit performance with the Business Markets segment on Slide #9. Business Markets reported third quarter revenues of $1 billion. This was flat with the prior year quarter and up 2% sequentially.
Recurring revenue held steady in the quarter both annually and sequentially. Similar to the 2009 trend, we did see sequential growth in data integration in the quarter.
In the enterprise space, we continue to see encouraging signs in customer activity and steadily increasing sales level. This segment also benefited from improved sales rep productivity and strong customer retention.
Strategic revenues in Business Markets now exceed legacy revenues for the first time since we began reported this mix. Strategic revenues increased 9% compared to the third quarter of 2009. This was driven by continued strong demand for our MPLS and high-capacity IP services. The growth in strategic revenues was offset by a 7% decline in legacy data and local voice services.
During the quarter, Qwest was a recipient for the third consecutive year of the prestigious Nemertes, PilotHouse Award and cited as Top Provider of Carrier Ethernet Services. Qwest outperformed every other market challenger in most categories achieving top ratings for customer service and overall value.
In the third quarter, Business Markets segment income of $415 million increased 4% year-over-year and 7% from the second quarter. The improvement in the quarter is driven by improved sales productivity and one-time legal settlements in the second quarter. Segment margin for the quarter expanded 140 basis points annually and 190 basis points sequentially to 40.7%.
In summary, we are encouraged by the increased activity and positive new sales momentum. We continue to expect revenues will start to pick up with economic conditions improve.
Results for our Wholesale segment are summarized on Slide #10. During the quarter, our Wholesale unit also received strong honor. For the 10th consecutive time, ATLANTIC-ACM recognized Qwest for best-in-class customer service, provisioning, network performance and billing in the ILEC categories as well as best-in-class across all carriers for data value.
For the first time in more than three years, Wholesale revenue held steady sequentially. Wholesale segment revenue for the quarter totaled $661 million, a decline of 8% year-over-year. Wholesale is benefiting from an improved strategic product mix that now represents 49% of total segment revenue.
Strategic revenues grew 6% compared with the prior year and 2% in the second quarter. This growth has been offset by declines in legacy voice services. However, legacy voice losses improved in the quarter as we saw less intense pressure in long distance grooming efforts.
Legacy revenues were down 1% sequentially which is a marked improvement from the 8% decline last quarter. The improved mix and demand for strategic services resulted in a 480 basis point increase in margins to 67.8%.
Our Wholesale Group continues to make significant progress in delivering fiber-based backhaul services for wireless carriers. We have completed construction and begun billing on fiber services for more than 1,000 sites and we continue to expect this to grow to about 2,000 sites by year-end.
As a reminder, we will have modest revenues from this program this year, and this initiative is expected to help mitigate wholesale revenue pressures over the next several quarters. Over the long run, this provides an avenue for strategic revenue growth.
Now, lets turn to Mass Markets result on slide #11. This unit achieved its fourth consecutive quarter of improved year-over-year revenue trends. Excluding the impact of the wireless reseller transition that was completed last year, Mass Markets revenue for the quarter declined 3% year-over-year and held steady sequentially.
Within Mass Markets, strategic revenues increased to 33% of segment revenue compared to 28% a year-ago. Strategic revenues improved 10% year-over-year while legacy revenue declined 9% due to continued pressure on traditional local voice services.
Consumer voice revenue now represents less than 20% of total consolidated revenue. In the third quarter, the companys high-speed Internet marketing campaign achieved good success.
We also experienced a stronger contribution from our small business units which reported improved revenue trends driven mainly by pricing actions. As a reminder, small business represents about 20% of Mass Markets total revenue or a little more than $900 million annually.
In the quarter, total expenses declined 9% from the third quarter of 2009, due to fewer employees, reduced wireless cost and lower sales and marketing expense. Mass Market segment income of $617 million declined 1% year-over-year and sequentially. Segment margin of 53% improved 190 basis points compared to the third quarter last year and declined 50 basis points sequentially.
Our quarterly subscriber results are shown slide 12. The number and rate of consumer and small business voice access line loss in the quarter improved on a year-over-year basis and held steady with the second quarter.
We continue to grow the revenues from customers we retained. Consumer ARPU improved during the quarter to $65, up 10% compared to the third quarter of 2009. The improvement was driven by growth in broadband, wireless and video users, and a higher speed mix within our broadband customer base.
We continue to expand our fiber-to-the-node footprint. Services are now available to approximately 4.5 million residential households. In the quarter, we added 92,000 new subscribers on fiber services and we now serve 620,000 broadband fiber subscribers.
At the end of the quarter in 2009, fiber-based customers numbered just 330,000. Fiber-to-the-node additions in the quarter were offset by a 52,000 subscriber decline in traditional ATM-based DSL.
As I mentioned, we are pleased with response we are seeing from launch of our high-speed internet promotional campaign during the quarter. The campaign is focused on full internet service and includes wireless, security and technical support.
Following the launch, call volumes and orders increased measurably. We also saw increased activity in online ordering through qwest.com, and finally, we benefited sequentially from positive seasonal influences in the third quarter.
In the quarter, video subscribers increased 12,000 to 963,000. This growth was also aided by seasonal influences such as the NFL package. Our wireless business continued to have strong performance in the quarter and now exceeds 1 million subscribers. We increased the number of Qwest-billed Verizon wireless users by 62,000.
In closing, I am pleased with the momentum we saw in the third quarter. We delivered solid operational results and improved top line performance across all segments. We achieved this while maintaining a sharp focus on expense management and disciplined investment.
I am confident we will continue to deliver solid results as we complete the remainder of the year. I look forward to updating you on our next call and now Ill turn it over to Joe.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Teresa. Good morning everyone and thank you for joining us today. In the third quarter, we again delivered another quarter of strong operating and financial performance. We met our goal of reducing the rate of loss of revenue to a low single-di
componenttext:
Thank you, Teresa. Good morning everyone and thank you for joining us today. In the third quarter, we again delivered another quarter of strong operating and financial performance. We met our goal of reducing the rate of loss of revenue to a low single-digit rate of decline a quarter ahead of schedule.
Adjusted EBITDA margin expanded to 38.2%. This represents another record margin for Qwest. We generated strong free cash flow in the quarter and we continued to improve our financial flexibility.
Now, lets start by turning to the income statement on slide 14. In the third quarter, consolidated revenues of $2.9 billion were flat sequentially for the first time in eight quarters and declined 4% compared to the prior year.
Excluding the impact of the wireless transition, revenues only declined 3% versus the prior year. As Teresa noted, the improved year-over-year comparison is due to stronger results in each segment.
Consolidated strategic services revenue grew 8% compared to the year ago quarter. Strategic services are larger contributor in each of our segments, mainly due to higher demand for fiber-based broadband services and IP solutions. In the quarter, strategic revenue grew to 39% of total revenue from 34% a year ago.
In addition to revenue performance improvements, we continue to maintain a disciplined focus on the bottom line. Total operating expenses improved 5% from the prior year. The improved operating costs are driven by our ongoing efforts to increase operating efficiency and productivity through balancing workforce to workload, process improvements and reductions in network facility cost.
Operating expenses increased 1% sequentially. The increase in the quarter was primarily due to realignment and severance cost of $51 million and a one-time adjustment related to USF fees of $15 million. Without the special items, expenses improved 1% sequentially.
Adjusted EBITDA of $1.1 billion for the quarter increased 3% from the year ago period and nearly 3% from the second quarter. Adjusted EBITDA margin of 38.2% expanded 240 basis points year-over-year and 90 basis points sequentially.
Moving on to Slide 15, we continue to strengthen the balance sheet in the third quarter and improve our financial flexibility. We ended the third quarter with net debt of $11 billion. This is a decline of $1 billion from the third quarter of 2009 and nearly $300 million from the second quarter.
Cash increased in the quarter to $2 billion. Net debt-to-annualized adjusted EBITDA was 2.5 times at the end of the quarter. This is another significant achievement and the lowest leverage ratio for the company since 1999.
Last month, we announced plans to redeem all of the companys convertible notes. Approximately $1.1 billion in principal was outstanding after tendering for a $147 million in August. We are well down the path to achieve our $3.5 billion stated debt reduction by February 2011.
Now, lets turn to Slide 16, which shows the details on adjusted free cash flow and capital expenditures. An improved revenue mix and continued diligent on expenses produce strong adjusted free cash flow, up $554 million in the quarter.
We continue to focus our capital spending on funding key fiber-based broadband initiatives. Capital expenditures were $373 million compared with $340 million in the third quarter of 2009 and $330 million last quarter.
In the quarter, our DSO of 38.6 days improved one full day compared to the year ago period. Our collection staff continues to execute very well. We achieved a 14% year-over-year improvement in bad debt expense, and bad debt is now less than 1% of total revenue.
Before I close with the discussion of our outlook, I would like to update you on our returns on invested capital on Slide 17. Cumulative return on invested capital for the last 12 months improved 60 basis points compared to the previous 12 months. This reflects steady net operating profit after-tax, while our asset base declined.
In fact, net PP&E is down $570 million year-over-year. With our current returns, we are earning above our internal estimate for our cost of capital, and as you can see the GAAP is improving.
Now, lets turn to our guidance on Slide #18. For the near-term, we continue to see a stable outlook for Business Markets. We expect to see enterprise revenue improve as the economy recovers.
In Wholesale, we are pleased with the steady top line trends in the quarter. Our goal is to continue to stabilize the top line sequentially and to report improving year-over-year rates of decline. In the fourth quarter, we expect Mass Markets to report a low single-digit sequential decline.
As Ed mentioned, we are raising our outlook overall for the year. We now expect consolidated revenues to decline at a low single-digit annual rate of decline in the fourth quarter similar to what we achieved this quarter one quarter ahead of schedule.
We also expect adjusted EBITDA to be at the high end of the range for the year of approximately $4.4 billion. We continue to expect capital investment of approximately $1.7 billion with about a $115 million of the investment to be financed by leasing. Our capital spending program reflects our focus on fiber-to-the-cell opportunities and our continued investment in fiber-to-the-node on an integrated basis.
Free cash flow for the year is now expected to be $1.7 billion to $1.8 billion with the benefit of the capital leasing activities. Without the benefit of the capital leasing activities, free cash flow was expected to be in the range of $1.6 billion to $1.7 billion.
As we stated last quarter regarding the pension, we do not expect to make any funding contributions to the pension plan in 2010 and our current expectation is that we will not have any required funding in 2011 as well.
Regarding taxes, we continue to expect to pay cash taxes of approximately 2% this year. As I mentioned, we will redeem our convert in the fourth quarter. In addition, we plan to make cash payment for the premium over the option strike price. The amount of this payment will depend on the future stock price. If you were to assume all holders convert with a stock price of $6.67, which was yesterdays close, this value would be approximately $450 million.
Returning value to shareholders remains a priority and we made a dividend payment of $0.08 per share or $139 million in the third quarter, and on October 21, the company announced a $0.08 per share dividend to be paid in the fourth quarter as well.
As we noted in the CenturyLink merger announcement, it is our current expectation that we will continue to pay a quarterly dividend of $0.08 per share through the close of the transaction. The merger agreement requires the company to coordinate with CenturyLink on dividend dates. As a result, the timing of future dividends may deviate from past dates due to this requirement.
In closing, Id like to reiterate how pleased I am with our results this quarter. We are confident that we will continue this momentum as we close out the year.
With that, Ill turn the call back over to the operator and well open the lines for questions.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Hey, guys, good morning. Thanks for taking the question. Congrats on the margin. Two questions if I could. First, Joe, could you call this quarter the inflection quarter for revenue? Can we start looking at this initial step-by-step growth in the sequenti
componenttext:
Hey, guys, good morning. Thanks for taking the question. Congrats on the margin. Two questions if I could. First, Joe, could you call this quarter the inflection quarter for revenue? Can we start looking at this initial step-by-step growth in the sequential revenue trends and extrapolate them, and if there are areas where we cant, could you walk us through what we should be expecting as we move in the right direction revenue-wise?
And then second, I think you guys have continued to mention that you dont have a cash contribution requirement for pensions this and next year, but I think you guys do end up showing up on a lot of screens in terms of pension liabilities relative to earnings power and market caps. So could you give us a little color on where you think the year-over-year earnings impact of the interest rate environment would be on the earnings contribution net income for the income statement?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me start with your first one. So if you remember back in February when we talked, we were talking about continuing to get down to this low single-digit rate to decline of revenue to at some point over the next coming year trying to hit that inflection
componenttext:
Let me start with your first one. So if you remember back in February when we talked, we were talking about continuing to get down to this low single-digit rate to decline of revenue to at some point over the next coming year trying to hit that inflection point. To hit that inflection point, you do need the economy to improve and the ability of our business market to get better growth than what weve been achieving to-date. So were close to the inflection point. Well continue to drive and reduce that rate of decline, but wed love to see some help from the economy.
In regards to the cash pension, youre exactly right, we have no cash funding requirements for 10 or 11, our liability you can see stated in the financial statements. If you were to cut things off today and revalued everything, youd probably have a bookkeeping charge going into 2011 and increase, but because youre only measuring it once a year, you just look at what happens to the marketplace by year end. What was the last question Dave?

componenttext: I guess Joe, just taking that pension expense issue a little further with interest rates lower, the liabilities are higher, the expenses are going to be higher your debt portfolio presumably is a little bit more valuable today than it was. If you net those things out, whats the earnings impact year-over-year as you look at the pension today?

Enterprise remains stable, but I was intrigued really to hear that the SMB segment was beginning to show some momentum, which is maybe a leading indicator for whats going to happen in enterprise. Any color on that would be very useful, whether its regional base or is it something youre seeing is throughout all your markets?

Is that how should I read your comments there and what are the implications for margins I assume that I mean in wholesale margins will remain stable going forward as well?

I think this was from activity that we caused in the marketplace in the way were repackaging and pricing and bundling. So I mean certainly the economy and the bankruptcies are still high in small business that still is a really rough market and the highly competitive.

componenttext:
I would say were probably catching up to them that they were ahead of us, and I can say that small business market is hypercompetitive with resellers and Qwest and its the cable companies and so with anything, we were following behind them and they were ahead of us.
And then on Wholesale, you are correct, we are through the phase where we were raising prices for long distance and where is the self-collection process, but Wholesale is still challenging and its local access is always a delicate area and we are getting good news in the private line area where the grooming has stopped a little bit and of course fiber-to-the-cell is giving us a way to offset some of those declines. So we see promising signs of wholesale, but this seems to be stabilizing out, but the local access site is still very tentative in how that market operates quarter-to-quarter.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, good morning. Thanks, guys. Wanted to hit on EBITDA, so, you guys raised guidance towards the top end of prior. If we look at that revised guidance and what you guys have done year-to-date, it would seem to imply about a 5% sequential drop to reach yo
componenttext:
Hi, good morning. Thanks, guys. Wanted to hit on EBITDA, so, you guys raised guidance towards the top end of prior. If we look at that revised guidance and what you guys have done year-to-date, it would seem to imply about a 5% sequential drop to reach your target in the fourth quarter. So, just wondering if there is something we should be thinking about in 4Q, maybe some of the seasonal costs that you expected in Q3 kind of got pushed into Q4 or what might cause a drop in 4Q EBITDA?
And then secondly on fiber-to-the-node, it looks like you reaccelerated the number of incremental homes in the quarter now tracking above $1 million for the year, which is kind of a target youve thrown out there before. Given the results that you guys have put up, is this something we should expect, maybe an accelerated pace of build-outs heading into 2011?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess on your last question, remember we are very focused on the integrated build and the fact that weve had such vibrant build on fiber-to-the-cell. We look to what additional homes we can get et cetera. So, were far more cost effective in the de
componenttext:
I guess on your last question, remember we are very focused on the integrated build and the fact that weve had such vibrant build on fiber-to-the-cell. We look to what additional homes we can get et cetera. So, were far more cost effective in the deployment of our capital than weve ever been before and the good news is, we did get a few extra homes out of it. But we will continue our disciplined approach of approximately 1 million homes a year and stay on that schedule. So, if we are able to get a few more homes as a result of deployment of fiber-to-the-cell, well take advantage of it.
In regards to the EBITDA question, remember, going into the fourth quarter you have sort of the seasonal declines as youre coming off business market sale start closing up for the November and December point. Some of the seasonal expenses we get out of our repairs and maintenance did maybe push in a little bit into the fourth quarter. But, overall, we are still very much on track to deliver the high-end of that range and have a consistent performance without any bumps in the night?

componenttext: Yes, absolutely, but thats not the big problem. I mean what we worry about here is not that because we are making it happen, right? Were encouraging our customers to do that, but were not just getting new adds into that portfolio and thats what we are focused on this quarter.

componenttext: Great. Thanks, guys. Sorry to beat a dead horse here on revenues though, but its interesting to see the legacy revenues doing a lot better. I know one quarter doesnt make a trend, but its kind of interesting that the access line volumes were a little weak and it sounds like on small business, youve been a little more aggressive on pricing. So, is it a pricing issue or volume issue or have we just hit a point on legacy volumes on kind of you mentioned private lines that maybe were seeing some stability. Just some thoughts on that because legacy revenues has been, obviously, the problem for you guys and for the whole industry? I do have other question on fiber if you dont mind.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me start. I think Tim, execution across the board has been very good for us. Weve talked historically about focusing on retention, focusing on how do we grow ARPU, and then trying to get that next new customer, and I think our churn rates, our bad
componenttext: Let me start. I think Tim, execution across the board has been very good for us. Weve talked historically about focusing on retention, focusing on how do we grow ARPU, and then trying to get that next new customer, and I think our churn rates, our bad debt rates, our ability to grow ARPU has been better than ever and very, very consistent in our execution on that and we continue to fight each day to gain that next new customer and weve been doing it on a far more integrated basis than we ever had before because we would like to hit that inflection point some point out in the future. So, I think its really execution in all of the segments focusing on those three things, in that order.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, consumer, Ill probably just add a little color by segments. I would answer a little differently to the Group. So, in the consumer space, we are seeing that slowdown. We obviously are very focused on premium high-speed internet in there and it does
componenttext:
Yes, consumer, Ill probably just add a little color by segments. I would answer a little differently to the Group. So, in the consumer space, we are seeing that slowdown. We obviously are very focused on premium high-speed internet in there and it does appear that maybe this has just slowed a bit. I wont say we found the bottom because I never know where the bottom is, but its definitely come into play. In the small business area, Ed mentioned earlier, still highly competitive. Weve had the opportunity to raise prices in some areas and lower prices in others through bundling.
And then in the Wholesale space, that grooming seems to have slowed down, that weve reached the point where all the carriers are where they want to be on their private line. It will be great if AT&T and Verizon had an uptick in their enterprise sales because that would benefit us on the wholesale side. But this seems stable. I would use that word right now on the legacy side. In the BMG space, we are aggressively trying to move our customers into the IP space. So, we encourage them and offer them incentives to get away from the legacy products and move into the strategic area.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the fiber side, the fiber-to-the-node, what are the customers experience in actually speeds when they have fiber-to-the-node versus your legacy kind of DSL and how do you think that compares to cable and maybe the same thing on ARPU, maybe you
componenttext: And then on the fiber side, the fiber-to-the-node, what are the customers experience in actually speeds when they have fiber-to-the-node versus your legacy kind of DSL and how do you think that compares to cable and maybe the same thing on ARPU, maybe you can talk about the difference in those customers? Thanks.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: So fiber-to-the-node to us is 7 megabits and higher, and by higher I mean up to 40, so thats where we stop at this point. Interesting enough that we have a promotion in the market where a customer could pick their speed and say, where they what to be a
componenttext:
So fiber-to-the-node to us is 7 megabits and higher, and by higher I mean up to 40, so thats where we stop at this point. Interesting enough that we have a promotion in the market where a customer could pick their speed and say, where they what to be and they did not pick the high-speed, they picked around 12, maybe 20.
So its an interesting phenomenon there what customers will actually pay for and what they are willing to absorb on a monthly bill. But in general, the cable companies do have more speed. Weve been very successful this last quarter with the promotion and with the new campaign that is not about speed, its about technical support and security and wireless access and that seems to be doing very well in the marketplace with our customers.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We continue to deploy at 40 megs, at the same cost we did 20 megs last year.
componenttext: We continue to deploy at 40 megs, at the same cost we did 20 megs last year.

componenttext: Hi. componenttext: No, I wish they would layoff. No, they are right in there, they have not seen at all. componenttext: Good morning, guys. I wonder if you could talk qualitatively about through the buckets of cost reduction you have, what areas are pretty well tapped out, what areas still have room to grow and also what sort of cost reduction areas are going to be dependent to a degree on continuing revenue declines and are there areas where you continue to take out absolute cost dollars even if revenue starts to recover?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: James, I think we continue to say that we go across the Board, its not any one point in time that we fix something to take cost out, and its an effort that everybody in the company works at everyday. So whether reducing the rates on variable cost to
componenttext:
James, I think we continue to say that we go across the Board, its not any one point in time that we fix something to take cost out, and its an effort that everybody in the company works at everyday. So whether reducing the rates on variable cost to improve gross margins, whether its the efficiencies we do to drive better fixed cost or the rates of what we pay for fixed cost or the continuing to balance workforce to workload, those are the things that is part of our DNA every day. Teresa and I along with the entire management team, we focus on that and lookout into the future.
So, its not about just focusing on whats happening in the coming quarter, but its about our plan to anticipate where the business is going out into the future and making sure that were well ahead of the curve and make sure that we can maintain that consistent EBITDA.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Qwest Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Kurt Fawkes, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Qwest Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Kurt Fawkes, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you. Good morning, everybody, and welcome to our call. We're going to begin the call today with comments on the quarter from Ed Mueller, our Chairman and CEO; then Ed will be followed by Teresa Taylor, our COO, who will review segment results.
componenttext:
Okay, thank you. Good morning, everybody, and welcome to our call. We're going to begin the call today with comments on the quarter from Ed Mueller, our Chairman and CEO; then Ed will be followed by Teresa Taylor, our COO, who will review segment results. And then Joe Euteneuer, our CFO, will conclude the prepared remarks with a discussion of our consolidated financial results and outlook. We will then open it up for your questions.
I want to point you to Slide 3 and remind everyone that today's discussion contains forward-looking statements. These statements are subject to significant risks and uncertainties. These risks and uncertainties are discussed in detail in our periodic filings with the SEC, and I strongly encourage you to thoroughly review our filings. I also want to note that we do not adopt analyst estimates, nor do we necessarily commit to updating any forward-looking statements that we will be making this morning.
To supplement the reporting of our financial information, on our call today, we will be discussing certain non-GAAP financial measures, including adjusted EBITDA, adjusted free cash flow and net debt. A full reconciliation of these measures is available on our website.
Now we'll move on to Slide 4 and touch on EPS and some special items that impacted EPS in the quarter. Our reported loss per share for the quarter was $0.05, and that compares to earnings per share of $0.08 in the third quarter of 2009. The current quarter includes a $0.13 charge related to the option on the convertible notes, a $0.02 charge for severance and realignment expense and a $0.01 charge for a one-time adjustment related to USF [Universal Service Fund] fees. 
Excluding special items, earnings per share were $0.11 in the third quarter.  That's a 22% improvement compared to $0.09 in the year ago quarter, as well as the second quarter of this year. Reported and adjusted earnings include dilution from non-cash pension OPEB expense. In the current quarter, the dilution was $0.01 and in the year ago period, we had an impact of $0.02. 
As a reminder, under the terms of the merger agreement with CenturyLink, we have committed to redeem our convertible debt and the value of the associated conversion rights for cash. Therefore, we previously reclassified the option component of the note from equity to a liability, which is included in accrued expense and other. The value of this liability at the end of the quarter was $349 million after initially being valued at $165 million on the date of the merger announcement. 
As a result of strong stock price appreciation during the third quarter, we reported a pre- and post-tax charge in the current period of $229 million to recognize the higher value of the option component of the convert. We have continued to see strong price appreciation in the fourth quarter. And as a result, we may have another charge when we report fourth quarter earnings. We'll be paying off the convertible principal and the value of the option in the fourth quarter.
With that, I'll now going to turn it over to Ed.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kurt. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I want to begin by saying, I'm very pleased with our execution and results we delivered in the quarter despite continued market challenges. We reported improved sequential and year-
componenttext:
Thanks, Kurt. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I want to begin by saying, I'm very pleased with our execution and results we delivered in the quarter despite continued market challenges. We reported improved sequential and year-over-year revenue trends, expanded margins and we generated strong cash flow.
In addition, we reported a number of significant achievements for the company this quarter, including record-high margins and record-low debt levels. I'm also very proud of the recognition we received during the quarter for customer service awards in both the enterprise and the wholesale units. Our performance is a strong evidence of the focus we have on our strategies to drive the top line while maintaining disciplined expense management to improving operating efficiencies.
We continue to see strong growth in our strategic revenues while we aggressively pursue fiber-based broadband services. We experienced a rebound to growth in subscriber additions, driven by demand for high-speed services, launch of a new marketing campaign and seasonal benefits. We also continued to strengthen our financial flexibility by improving the balance sheet. Our progress was recognized by a rating agency upgrade in August to investment grade. 
During the quarter, we announced plans to call our convertible debt, which totals $1.1 billion in principal, and are well on the path to achieve our stated debt reduction goals. In addition, I'm very happy with the progress we're making toward the completion of our merger with CenturyLink. The senior leadership team for the combined company has been named. The second-tier team was also recently announced. Activities are well underway in the planning process for the integration of the two companies. We have reached several key milestones in the approval process, including overwhelming support from both company shareholders.
Last month, our unions agreed that the merger is in the public interest, and withdrew all opposition. We continue to make progress with various agencies and commissions required to review the transaction. To date, we've received approvals in 12 states. In addition to the FCC, we have 10 states remaining to review and approve the transaction.
To sum up, we've had a solid execution in the quarter, and we're well on the path to achieve our stated objectives. We are confident we will continue to execute for the remainder of the year. As a result, we are raising our revenue, EBITDA and free cash flow outlook to the top end of the 2010 guidance. Joe will provide you with the details.
We continue to expect our merger with CenturyLink to close in the first half of 2011. We're excited about the prospects that will arise from the combination of our two companies. Our respective shareholders have already benefited from the operating and stock performance of the two companies since our announcement.
Looking ahead, Qwest shareholders will benefit from significant synergies, a nearly 50% increase in dividends from today's level, accelerated deleveraging of the balance sheet, a strong management team and a talented employee base. I remain firmly convinced this transaction will further bolster our results and drive superior shareholder value. 
Now I'll hand it off to Teresa, who will discuss our business unit performance.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ed, and good morning, everyone. I'm very pleased with our performance in the third quarter. Under challenging market conditions, we continue to deliver on our goal to improve the top line trend. In the quarter, all three segments again reported
componenttext:
Thank you, Ed, and good morning, everyone. I'm very pleased with our performance in the third quarter. Under challenging market conditions, we continue to deliver on our goal to improve the top line trend. In the quarter, all three segments again reported improved revenue trends on both the sequential and year-over-year basis. We achieved solid subscriber additions on our fiber-to-the-node network, maintained steady performance in Business Markets and improved top line trends in Wholesale.
Solid customer demand for strategic products continue to provide an increasing revenue contribution in each of the units. Total strategic revenue grew 8% compared to the year ago quarter, driven by 24% growth in enterprise IP services and growth in residential fiber-based services. This compares to 6% year-over-year growth in the second quarter.
Legacy revenue losses improved substantially in the quarter as well. Sequentially, legacy revenue was down 1% in the quarter compared with 4% last quarter.
We also continue to maintain a disciplined focus on the bottom line. Adjusted EBITDA and operating income both increased nearly 3% compared to the prior year. And we'll begin the discussion of our individual business unit performance with the Business Market segment on Slide 9. 
Business Markets reported third quarter revenues of $1 million. This is flat with the prior year quarter and up 2% sequentially. Recurring revenue held steady in the quarter, both annually and sequentially. Similar to the 2009 trend, we did see sequential growth in data integration in the quarter.
In the Enterprise space, we continue to see encouraging signs in customer activity and steadily increasing sales levels. This segment also benefited from improved sales rep productivity and strong customer retention. Strategic revenue in Business Markets now exceed the legacy revenue for the first time since we began reporting this mix. Strategic revenues increased 9% compared to the third quarter of 2009. This was driven by a continued strong demand for our MPLS [Multiprotocol Label Switching] and high-capacity IP services. The growth in strategic revenues was offset by a 7% decline in legacy data and local voice services.
During the quarter, Qwest was a recipient for the third consecutive year of the prestigious Nemertes PilotHouse Award and cited top provider of carrier Internet services. Qwest outperformed every other market challenger in most categories, achieving top ratings for customer service and overall value. 
In the third quarter, Business Markets segment income of $415 million increased 4% year-over-year and 7% from the second quarter. The improvement in the quarter is driven by improved sales productivity and a one-time legal settlement in the second quarter. Segment margin for the quarter expanded 140 basis points annually and 190 basis points sequentially to 40.7%.
In summary, we are encouraged by the increased activity and positive new sales momentum. We continue to expect revenues will start to pick up as economic conditions improve. 
Results for our Wholesale segment are summarized on Slide 10. During the quarter, our Wholesale unit also received strong honors. For the 10th consecutive time, Atlantic-ACM recognized Qwest for best-in-class customer service, provisioning, network performance and billing in the ILEC [Incumbent Local Exchange Carrier] category, as well as best in class across all carriers for data value.
For the first time in more than three years, Wholesale revenue held steady sequentially. Wholesale segment revenue for the quarter totaled $661 million, a decline of 8% year-over-year. Wholesale is benefiting from an improved strategic product mix that now represents 49% of total segment revenue. 
Strategic revenues grew 6% compared with the prior year and 2% in the second quarter. This growth is being offset by declines in legacy voice services. However, legacy voice losses improved in the quarter as we saw less intense pressure in long distance and grooming efforts. Legacy revenues were down 1% sequentially, which is a marked improvement from the 8% decline last quarter. The improved mix and demand for strategic services resulted in a 480-basis-point increase in margin to 67.8%. 
Our Wholesale group continues to make significant progress in delivering fiber-based backhaul services for wireless carriers. We have completed construction and began billing on fiber services for more than 1,000 sites, and we continue to expect this to grow to about 2,000 sites by year end. 
As a reminder, we will have modest revenues from this program this year, and this initiative is expected to help mitigate Wholesale revenue pressures over the next several quarters. For the long run, this provides an avenue for strategic revenue growth. 
Now let's turn to Mass Markets results on Slide 11. This unit achieved its fourth consecutive quarter of improved year-over-year revenue trend. Excluding the impact of the wireless reseller transition that was completed last year, Mass Markets revenue for the quarter declined 3% year-over-year and held steady sequentially. Within Mass Markets, strategic revenues increased to 33% of segment revenue compared to 28% a year ago. Strategic revenues improved 10% year-over-year while legacy revenue declined 9% due to continued pressure on traditional local voice services.
Consumer voice revenue now represents less than 20% of total consolidated revenue. In the third quarter, the company's High-Speed Internet marketing campaign achieved good success. We also experienced a stronger contribution from our Small business unit, which reported improved revenue trends, driven mainly by pricing action. As a reminder, Small Business represents about 20% of Mass Markets' total revenue, or a little more than $900 million annually. 
In the quarter, total expenses declined 9% in the third quarter of 2009 due to fewer employees, reduced wireless costs and lower sales and marketing expense. Mass Markets segment income of $617 million declined 1% year-over-year and sequentially. Segment margin of 53% improved to 190 basis points compared to the third quarter last year and declined 50 basis points sequentially. 
Our quarterly subscribers results are shown on Slide 12. The number and rate of consumer and small business voice access line loss in the quarter improved on a year-over-year basis and held steady with the second quarter. We continue to grow the revenues from customers we retained. Consumer ARPU improved during the quarter to $65, up 10% compared to the third quarter of 2009. The improvement was driven by growth in broadband, wireless and video users. And a higher speed mix was in our broadband customer base. 
We continue to expand our fiber-to-the-node footprint. Services are now available to approximately 4.5 million residential households. In the quarter, we added 92,000 new subscribers on fiber services. And we now serve 620,000 broadband fiber subscribers. At the end of the quarter in 2009, fiber-based customers numbered just 330,000. Fiber-to-the-node additions in the quarter were offset by a 52,000-subscriber decline in traditional ATM-based DSL. 
As I mentioned, we are pleased with the response we are seeing from the launch of our new High-Speed Internet promotional campaign during the quarter. The campaign is focused on full Internet service and includes wireless, security, and technical support. Following the launch, call volumes of orders increased measurably. We also saw increased activity in online ordering through qwest.com. And finally, we benefited sequentially from positive seasonal influences in the third quarter.
In the quarter, video subscribers increased 12,000 to 963,000. This growth was also aided by seasonal influences such as the NFL package. Our Wireless business continued to have a strong performance in the quarter and now exceeds 1 million subscribers. The increase in number of Qwest-billed Verizon Wireless users by 62,000. 
In closing, I'm pleased with the momentum we saw in the third quarter. We delivered solid operational results and improved top line performance across all segments. We achieved this while maintaining a sharp focus on expense management and disciplined investments. I am confident we will continue to deliver solid results as we complete the remainder of the year. I look forward to updating you on our next call.
And now I'll turn it over to Joe.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Teresa. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. In third quarter, we again delivered another quarter of strong operating and financial performance. We met our goal of reducing the rate of loss of revenue to a low-single digi
componenttext:
Thank you, Teresa. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. In third quarter, we again delivered another quarter of strong operating and financial performance. We met our goal of reducing the rate of loss of revenue to a low-single digit rate of decline a quarter ahead of schedule.
Adjusted EBITDA margin expanded to 38.2%. This represents another record margin for Qwest. We generated strong free cash flow in the quarter, and we continued to improve our financial flexibility.
Now let's start by turning to the income statement on Slide 14. In the third quarter, consolidated revenues of $2.9 billion were flat sequentially for the first time in eight quarters and declined 4% compared to the prior year. Excluding the impact of the wireless transition, revenues only declined 3% versus the prior year. As Teresa noted, the improved year-over-year comparison is due to stronger results in each segment. Consolidated strategic services revenue grew 8% compared to the year ago quarter. Strategic services are a larger contributor in each of our segments, mainly due to higher demand for fiber-based broadband services and IP solutions. In the quarter, strategic revenue grew to 39% of total revenue from 34% a year ago.
In addition to revenue performance improvements, we continue to maintain a disciplined focus on the bottom line. Total operating expenses improved 5% from the prior year. The improved operating costs are driven by our ongoing efforts to increase operating efficiency and productivity through balancing workforce to workload, process improvements and reductions in network facility costs. 
Operating expenses increased 1% sequentially. The increase in the quarter was primarily due to realignment and severance cost of $51 million and a one-time adjustment related to USF fees of $15 million. Without the special items, expenses improved 1% sequentially. Adjusted EBITDA of $1.1 billion for the quarter increased 3% from the year ago period and nearly 3% from the second quarter. Adjusted EBITDA margin of 38.2% expanded 240 basis points year-over-year and 90 basis points sequentially.
Moving on to Slide 15. We continued to strengthen the balance sheet in the third quarter and improve our financial flexibility. We ended the third quarter with net debt of $11 billion. This is a decline of $1 billion from the third quarter of 2009 and nearly $300 million from the second quarter. Cash increased in the quarter to $2 billion. Net debt to annualized adjusted EBITDA was 2.5x at the end of the quarter. This is another significant achievement and the lowest leverage ratio for the company since 1999.
Last month, we announced plans to redeem all of the company's convertible notes. Approximately $1.1 billion in principal is outstanding after tendering for $147 million in August. We are well down the path to achieve our $3.5 billion stated debt reduction by February 2011.
Now let's turn to Slide 16, which shows the details on adjusted free cash flow and capital expenditures. An improved revenue mix and continued diligence on expenses produced strong adjusted free cash flow of $554 million in the quarter. We continue to focus our capital spending on funding key fiber-based broadband initiatives. Capital expenditures were $373 million compared with $340 million in the third quarter of 2009 and $330 million last quarter.
In the quarter, our DSO of 38.6 days improved one full day compared to the year ago period. Our collections staff continues to execute very well. We achieved a 14% year-over-year improvement in bad debt expense, and bad debt is now less than 1% of total revenue.
Before I close with the discussion of our outlook, I would like to update you on our returns on invested capital on Slide 17. Cumulative return on invested capital for the last 12 months improved 60 basis points compared to the previous 12 months. This reflects steady net operating profit after tax while our asset base declined. In fact, net PP&E is down $570 million year-over-year. With our current returns, we are earning above our internal estimate for our cost of capital, and as you can see, the gap is improving.
Now let's turn to our guidance on Slide 18. For the near term, we continue to see a stable outlook for Business Markets. We expect to see enterprise revenue improve as the economy recovers. In Wholesale, we are pleased with the steady top line trends in the quarter. Our goal is to continue to stabilize the top line sequentially and to report improving year-over-year rates of decline. In the fourth quarter, we expect Mass Markets to report a low-single digit sequential decline. As Ed mentioned, we are raising our outlook overall for the year. We now expect consolidated revenues to decline at a low-single digit annual rate of decline in the fourth quarter, similar to what we achieved this quarter, one quarter ahead of schedule.
We also expect adjusted EBITDA to be at the high end of the range for the year of approximately $4.4 billion. We continue to expect capital investment of approximately $1.7 billion, with about $150 million of the investment to be financed by leasing. Our capital spending program reflects our focus on Fiber-to-the-Cell opportunities and our continued investment in fiber-to-the-node on an integrated basis.
Free cash flow for the year is now expected to be $1.7 billion to $1.8 billion with the benefit of the capital leasing activities. Without the benefit of the capital leasing activities, free cash flow is expected to be in the range of $1.6 billion to $1.7 billion.
As we stated last quarter regarding the pension, we do not expect to make any funding contributions to the pension plan in 2010. And our current expectation is that we will not have any required funding in 2011 as well.
Regarding taxes, we continue to expect to pay cash taxes of approximately 2% this year. As I mentioned, we will redeem our convert in the fourth quarter. In addition, we plan to make a cash payment for the premium over the option strike price. The amount of this payment will depend on the future stock price. If you were to assume all holders convert with a stock price of $6.67, which was yesterday's close, this value would be approximately $450 million.
Returning value to shareholders remains a priority, and we made a dividend payment of $0.08 per share or $139 million in the third quarter. And on October 21, the company announced an $0.08-per-share dividend to be paid in the fourth quarter as well.
As we noted in the CenturyLink merger announcement, it is our current expectation that we will continue to pay a quarterly dividend of $0.08 per share through the close of the transaction. The merger agreement requires the company to coordinate with CenturyLink on dividend dates. As a result, the timing of future dividends may deviate from past dates due to this requirement.
In closing, I'd like to reiterate how pleased I am with our results this quarter. We are confident that we will continue this momentum as we close out the year. 
With that, I'll turn the call back over to the Operator, and we'll open the lines for questions.

componenttext: And just out of curiosity, I think, if you go back a year ago, the question was how long can you keep EBITDA at or above the current levels while seeing some of the erosion in revenue. Is there a ratio or some way the investors should be thinking about that relationship?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: First, Joe, could you kind of call this quarter the inflection quarter for revenue? Can we start looking at this initial kind of step-by-step growth in the sequential revenue trends and kind of extrapolate them? And if there are areas where we can't, coul
componenttext: First, Joe, could you kind of call this quarter the inflection quarter for revenue? Can we start looking at this initial kind of step-by-step growth in the sequential revenue trends and kind of extrapolate them? And if there are areas where we can't, could you kind of walk us through what we should be expecting as we kind of move in the right direction revenue-wise? And second, I think you guys have kind of continued to mention that you don't have a cash contribution requirement for pensions this and next year. But I think you guys do end up showing up on a lot of screens in terms of pension liabilities relative to earnings power and market cap. So could you kind of give us a little color on where you think the year-over-year earnings impact of kind of the interest rate environment would be on the earnings contribution net income for the income statement?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me start with your first one. So if you remember back in February when we talked, we were talking about continuing to get down to this low-single digit rate of decline of revenue to at some point over the next coming year trying to hit that inflection
componenttext: Let me start with your first one. So if you remember back in February when we talked, we were talking about continuing to get down to this low-single digit rate of decline of revenue to at some point over the next coming year trying to hit that inflection point. To hit that inflection point, you do need the economy to improve and the ability of our business markets to get better growth than what we've been achieving to date. So we're close to the infection point. We'll continue to drive and reduce that rate of decline, but we'd love to see some help from the economy. In regards to the cash pension, you're exactly right. We have no cash funding requirements for '10 or '11. Our liability, you can see stated in the financial statements, if you were to cut things off today and revalued everything, you would probably have a bookkeeping charge going into 2011, an increase. But because you're only measuring it once a year, you just sort of look at what happens to the marketplace by year end. And your last question, what was the last question, Dave?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, Joe, just kind of taking that pension expense issue a little further. With interest rates lower, the liabilities are higher, the expenses are going to be higher, your debt portfolio presumably is a little bit more valuable today than it was. If y
componenttext: I guess, Joe, just kind of taking that pension expense issue a little further. With interest rates lower, the liabilities are higher, the expenses are going to be higher, your debt portfolio presumably is a little bit more valuable today than it was. If you net those things out, what's the earnings impact year-over-year as you look at the pension today?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: So for next year, you would have an increase of pension expense. We haven't come up -- we won't be able to measure that until year end when we get the final numbers. But based on where things are today, we would think that there would be somewhat of an in
componenttext: So for next year, you would have an increase of pension expense. We haven't come up -- we won't be able to measure that until year end when we get the final numbers. But based on where things are today, we would think that there would be somewhat of an increase.

componenttext: And I just want to continue on that revenue theme, and just take it a little bit further down. Enterprise remains stable. I was intrigued to hear that SMB segment was beginning to show some momentum, which is maybe a leading indicator for what's going to happen in enterprise. Any color on that would be very useful, whether its regional base or is it something you've seen throughout all your markets. Second question on wholesale.  I guess what I read into the commentary by Joe is that the grooming, the price increases that you've implemented in wholesale to get your customers to self-select, that phase is largely over and now the top line should remain relatively stable. Is that how shall I read your comments there? And what are the implications for margins? I assume that it means that wholesale margins will remain stable going forward as well.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Peter, this is Teresa. In the small business market, a lot of our movements this last quarter was in pricing and bundling activity. So I'm not really in a place to say that small business is turning around. I think this was some activity that we caused in
componenttext: Peter, this is Teresa. In the small business market, a lot of our movements this last quarter was in pricing and bundling activity. So I'm not really in a place to say that small business is turning around. I think this was some activity that we caused in the marketplace in the way we're repackaging and pricing and bundling. So we still need the economy. I mean, the bankruptcies are still high in small business, that's still the really rough market and highly competitive.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We're always looking maybe ahead. But did your competitors follow suit on the price increases by any chance?
componenttext: We're always looking maybe ahead. But did your competitors follow suit on the price increases by any chance?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I would say we were probably catching up to them, because they were ahead of us. And like I said, the small business market is hypercompetitive with resellers and class and the cable companies. And so if anything, we were following behind them. They were
componenttext: I would say we were probably catching up to them, because they were ahead of us. And like I said, the small business market is hypercompetitive with resellers and class and the cable companies. And so if anything, we were following behind them. They were ahead of us. And then on wholesale, you are correct. We are through the phase where we were raising prices for long distance and having the self-selection process. But wholesale is still challenging and local access is always a delicate area. And we are getting good news in the private line area where the grooming had stopped a little bit. And of course Fiber-to-the-Cell is giving us a way to offset some of those declines. So we see promising signs at wholesale that it seems to be stabilizing out, but that local access site is still very tentative in how that market operates quarter-to-quarter.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: On that local access site, is that getting worse in terms of momentum?
componenttext: On that local access site, is that getting worse in terms of momentum?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Right now, it's actually stabilized. But I've seen this a number of years. It goes up and down. It's volatile.
componenttext: Right now, it's actually stabilized. But I've seen this a number of years. It goes up and down. It's volatile.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: It's hard to predict. And the good news for the wholesale group is the fact that the Fiber-to-the-Cell continues to be a pretty vibrant environment. We have construction scheduled now well into 2011. So that is the growth revenue coming into the segment t
componenttext: It's hard to predict. And the good news for the wholesale group is the fact that the Fiber-to-the-Cell continues to be a pretty vibrant environment. We have construction scheduled now well into 2011. So that is the growth revenue coming into the segment that will help offset some of these potential declines that we've gotten a lot out of the system, but we can't be positive that it's 100% done.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll now hear from Scott Goldman with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll now hear from Scott Goldman with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to hit on EBITDA. So you guys raised guidance towards the top end of prior. If we look at that revised guidance when you guys are done year-to-date, would seem to imply about a 5% sequential drop to reach your target in the fourth quarter. So I'm
componenttext: I wanted to hit on EBITDA. So you guys raised guidance towards the top end of prior. If we look at that revised guidance when you guys are done year-to-date, would seem to imply about a 5% sequential drop to reach your target in the fourth quarter. So I'm just wondering if there's something we should be thinking about in 4Q, maybe some of the seasonal costs that you expect in 3Q kind of pushing to 4Q. Or what might cause a drop in 4Q EBITDA? And then secondly on fiber-to-the-node, it looks like you've accelerated the number of incrementals homes in the quarter, now tracking above the 1 million for the year, which is kind of a target you've thrown out there before. And given the results that you guys have put up, is this something we should expect maybe an accelerated pace of build-outs heading into 2011?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess on your last question, remember, we are very focused on the integrated build and the fact that we've had such vibrant build on Fiber-to-the-Cell. We look to what additional homes we can get, et cetera. So we're far more cost effective in the deplo
componenttext: I guess on your last question, remember, we are very focused on the integrated build and the fact that we've had such vibrant build on Fiber-to-the-Cell. We look to what additional homes we can get, et cetera. So we're far more cost effective in the deployment of our capital than we've ever been before, and the good news is we did get a few extra homes out of it. But we will continue our disciplined approach of approximately 1 million homes a year and stay on that schedule. So if we are able to get a few more homes as a result of the employment of Fiber-to-the-Cell, we'll take advantage of it. In regards to your EBITDA question, remember, going into the fourth quarter, we have sort of the seasonal decline. As you're coming off, Business Markets sales start closing up for the November and December point. Some of the seasonal expenses we get out of our repairs and maintenance maybe pushing a little bit into the fourth quarter. But overall, we are still very much on track to deliver the high end of that range and have a consistent performance without any bumps in the night.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
