componenttext: One quick follow up on the fiber-to-the-node. Can you just tell us again maybe how much of the DSO losses are really just migrations over to the fiber-to-the-node platform?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, what we're seeing is we're not getting new adds in. For the losses, I mean, the churn rate is good, actually, one of the best we've ever had. But we're not getting the growth adds in. So what's happening is we're just not getting the new sales, and
componenttext: Scott, what we're seeing is we're not getting new adds in. For the losses, I mean, the churn rate is good, actually, one of the best we've ever had. But we're not getting the growth adds in. So what's happening is we're just not getting the new sales, and that's what we're focused on this quarter.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: But those are not a part of those losses that are going over to the fiber-to-the-node?
componenttext: But those are not a part of those losses that are going over to the fiber-to-the-node?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, but that's not the big problem. What we worry about here is not that, because we're making it happen, right? We're encouraging our customers to do that. But we're just not getting new adds into that portfolio. And that's what we're focused on
componenttext: Absolutely, but that's not the big problem. What we worry about here is not that, because we're making it happen, right? We're encouraging our customers to do that. But we're just not getting new adds into that portfolio. And that's what we're focused on this quarter.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll now hear from Tim Horan with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: We'll now hear from Tim Horan with Oppenheimer.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Sorry to beat a dead horse here on revenue, but it's interesting to see the legacy revenues doing a lot better. I know one quarter doesn't make a trend. But it's kind of interesting, the access line volumes were a little weak, and it sounds like on small
componenttext: Sorry to beat a dead horse here on revenue, but it's interesting to see the legacy revenues doing a lot better. I know one quarter doesn't make a trend. But it's kind of interesting, the access line volumes were a little weak, and it sounds like on small business, you've been a little more aggressive on pricing. So is it a pricing issue or a volume issue or we just hit a point on legacy volumes on kind of -- you mentioned private lines that may be worsening some stability. Just some thoughts on that because it's clearly been the legacy revenues have been obviously the problem for you guys and for the whole industry.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me start by, I think, Tim, execution across the board has been very good for us. We've talked historically about focusing on retention, focusing on how do we grow our ARPU and then trying to get that next new customer. And I think our churn rates, our
componenttext: Let me start by, I think, Tim, execution across the board has been very good for us. We've talked historically about focusing on retention, focusing on how do we grow our ARPU and then trying to get that next new customer. And I think our churn rates, our bad debt rates, our ability to grow ARPU has been better than ever and very, very consistent in our execution on that. And we continue to fight each day to gain that next new customer, and we've been doing it on a far more integrated basis than we ever have before, because we would like to hit that inflection point at some point out in the future. So I think it's really execution in all of the segments, focusing on those three things in that order.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I'd probably just add a little color by segment, so I would answer a little differently to the group. So in the consumer space, we are seeing that slow down. We obviously are very focused on premium high-speed Internet in there, and it does appear that th
componenttext: I'd probably just add a little color by segment, so I would answer a little differently to the group. So in the consumer space, we are seeing that slow down. We obviously are very focused on premium high-speed Internet in there, and it does appear that this just slowed a bit, and also we saw the bottom because I never know where the bottom is, but it definitely come into play. In the small business area, we have mentioned earlier, still highly competitive. We've had the opportunity to raise prices in some areas and lower prices in others through bundling. And then in the wholesale space, we're really just -- that grooming thing seems to slow down. We've reached the point where all the carriers are where they want to be on their private line. It would be great if AT&T and Verizon had an uptick in their enterprise sales, because that would benefit us on the wholesale side. It just seems stable. I would use that word right now on the legacy side. In the BMG space, we are aggressively trying to move our customers into the IP space. So we encourage them and offer them incentives to get away from legacy products and move into strategic area.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the fiber side, the fiber-to-the-node, what are the customers' experience in actual speeds when they have fiber-to-the-node versus your legacy kind of DSL, and how do you think that compares to cable?  And maybe the same thing in ARPU, maybe y
componenttext: And then on the fiber side, the fiber-to-the-node, what are the customers' experience in actual speeds when they have fiber-to-the-node versus your legacy kind of DSL, and how do you think that compares to cable?  And maybe the same thing in ARPU, maybe you can talk about the difference in those customers.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: So fiber-to-the-node to us is seven megabits and higher. And by higher, I mean up to 40. So that's where we stop at this point. Interesting enough that we had a promotion in the market where the customer could pick their speed and say where they want to b
componenttext: So fiber-to-the-node to us is seven megabits and higher. And by higher, I mean up to 40. So that's where we stop at this point. Interesting enough that we had a promotion in the market where the customer could pick their speed and say where they want to be, and they did not pick the high speeds. They picked around 12, maybe 20. So it was an interesting phenomenon there, what customers will actually pay for and what they are willing to absorb on a monthly bill. But in general, the cable companies do have more speed. We've been very successful this last quarter with the promotion and with a new campaign, but it's not about speed, it's about technical support and security and wireless access and that seems to be doing very well in the marketplace with our customers.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We continue to deploy at 40 megs at the same cost we did 20 megs last year.
componenttext: We continue to deploy at 40 megs at the same cost we did 20 megs last year.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And how is your ARPU for the customers legacy versus fiber-to-the-node? Is there much difference?
componenttext: And how is your ARPU for the customers legacy versus fiber-to-the-node? Is there much difference?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Fiber-to-the-node is significantly higher. The legacy is the ATM speed. So that's very low monthly rate, where when you get up into the fiber, you can go as high as $100 a month. It can go all the way up.
componenttext: Fiber-to-the-node is significantly higher. The legacy is the ATM speed. So that's very low monthly rate, where when you get up into the fiber, you can go as high as $100 a month. It can go all the way up.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And Chris Larsen with Piper Jaffray has our next question.
componenttext: And Chris Larsen with Piper Jaffray has our next question.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, I was going to -- on that same line of thinking, Teresa, you talked about less port-outs. Are we seeing less wireless substitution? Are we seeing less competition from the cable VoIPs [Voice over IP]? Is there a less competitive environment? Do
componenttext: Actually, I was going to -- on that same line of thinking, Teresa, you talked about less port-outs. Are we seeing less wireless substitution? Are we seeing less competition from the cable VoIPs [Voice over IP]? Is there a less competitive environment? Do you think that we've sort of hit the point where there's less to be taken? I just wondered if you could just talk a little bit about what the competitive dynamics are. We've also seen some slightly better numbers than some of the other goals, and I'm wondering if the cable has laid off the competitive pedal, so to speak, for the quarter. Could we see that swing back?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I wish they would lay off. No, they're right in there. They've not changed at all. They're extremely aggressive, and if anything, maybe, Chris, we're trading customers. That's probably what's happening a lot, and we continue to look for expansion to bring
componenttext: I wish they would lay off. No, they're right in there. They've not changed at all. They're extremely aggressive, and if anything, maybe, Chris, we're trading customers. That's probably what's happening a lot, and we continue to look for expansion to bring in new customers. I mean, it's still a question are -- a lot of people, believe it or not, are still at low speed and maybe even dialing up in some rural areas. But we're trying to bring customers into the higher speeds, and I think our current results reflect that we're doing okay with that right now. But the cable companies are extremely competitive. They are not letting up at all.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: On the voice side, though, are you seeing less port-outs substitution or less-port outs to cable VoIP or anything that would indicate why you're seeing an improvement there?
componenttext: On the voice side, though, are you seeing less port-outs substitution or less-port outs to cable VoIP or anything that would indicate why you're seeing an improvement there?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, so you mean on the voice line?
componenttext: Yes, so you mean on the voice line?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: No. I was talking both, but yes, specifically on the resi [residential] voice mail.
componenttext: No. I was talking both, but yes, specifically on the resi [residential] voice mail.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: On the high-speed, we do not see wireless interfering with that. But we do see that customers will disconnect their voice landlines for wireless substitutions, that continues to increase. But we also see something that as people are disconnecting their vo
componenttext: On the high-speed, we do not see wireless interfering with that. But we do see that customers will disconnect their voice landlines for wireless substitutions, that continues to increase. But we also see something that as people are disconnecting their voice lines and going nowhere. I mean, maybe they had wireless, but they're not going to VoIP, I guess, is just another way to look at that. And we don't see a lot of activities there. Either they're disconnecting completely, or they're disconnecting and going to wireless.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Simon Flannery with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is from Simon Flannery with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could give us an update, you talked about the states and the FCC remaining. Can you be a bit more specific about what this sort of latest timelines out of some of the states are as we think through the next few months?  And then, Teresa, y
componenttext: I wonder if you could give us an update, you talked about the states and the FCC remaining. Can you be a bit more specific about what this sort of latest timelines out of some of the states are as we think through the next few months?  And then, Teresa, you talked I think back in February about CyberCenter as being one of the growth opportunities. Perhaps you could just update us on what you're seeing there.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Simon, this is Ed. The timeline, it's kind of like we've laid out before. I would say the hearing schedule -- if you went to a hearing schedule, that's why we're cautious here, because if you had to go all the way through a hearing, that's why we're confi
componenttext: Simon, this is Ed. The timeline, it's kind of like we've laid out before. I would say the hearing schedule -- if you went to a hearing schedule, that's why we're cautious here, because if you had to go all the way through a hearing, that's why we're confident in the first half. It depends on if we can make agreements, it'll be to our benefit. And so I'm really confident that the 10 states that are left, plus the FCC, are moving in an orderly and a good way for our shareholders. So more to come. We announced as we get an agreement in a state, we probably put that out, and we'll continue to do that.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And Simon, on our CyberCenter, we're happy with the results. I would call it stable. The revenue is slightly up. And we continue to look for opportunities to open new centers, but I don't think we're quite ready to announce that yet. But we're always look
componenttext: And Simon, on our CyberCenter, we're happy with the results. I would call it stable. The revenue is slightly up. And we continue to look for opportunities to open new centers, but I don't think we're quite ready to announce that yet. But we're always looking for ability to expand that footprint.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: So you're pretty high on utilization with what you have right now?
componenttext: So you're pretty high on utilization with what you have right now?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's why we're looking for opportunities to expand. Looking for cheap real estate.
componenttext: Yes, that's why we're looking for opportunities to expand. Looking for cheap real estate.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from James Ratcliffe with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from James Ratcliffe with Barclays Capital.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you could talk qualitatively about through the buckets of cost reduction you have. What areas are pretty well tapped out? What areas still have room to go, and also what sort of cost reduction areas are going to be dependent to a degree o
componenttext: I'm wondering if you could talk qualitatively about through the buckets of cost reduction you have. What areas are pretty well tapped out? What areas still have room to go, and also what sort of cost reduction areas are going to be dependent to a degree on continuing revenue declines? And are there areas where you can continue to take out absolute cost dollars even if revenue starts to recover?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: James, I think we continue to say that we go across the board. It's not any one point in time that we pick something to take cost out. It's an effort that everybody in the company looks at every day. So whether it's taking reducing the rates on variable c
componenttext: James, I think we continue to say that we go across the board. It's not any one point in time that we pick something to take cost out. It's an effort that everybody in the company looks at every day. So whether it's taking reducing the rates on variable costs to improve gross margins, whether it's the efficiencies we do to drive better fixed costs or the rates of what we pay for fixed costs or the continuing to balance work force to workload, those are things that is part of our DNA. Every day, Teresa and I, along with the entire management team, we focus on that and look out into the future. So it's not about just focusing on what's happening in the coming quarter, but it's about our plan to anticipate where the business is going out into the future and making sure that we're well ahead of the curve and make sure that we can maintain that consistent EBITDA.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: James, like I was saying earlier, as we get some revenue relief, if you want to think of it that way, the expense side does not have to be reduced as much in order for us to hold where we want to be. And that's why we're very happy this quarter with how t
componenttext: James, like I was saying earlier, as we get some revenue relief, if you want to think of it that way, the expense side does not have to be reduced as much in order for us to hold where we want to be. And that's why we're very happy this quarter with how the revenue is starting to slow down in that rate of decline.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Our last question today comes from Dave Coleman with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our last question today comes from Dave Coleman with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you just talk about your Fiber-to-the-Cell business to sort of capacity volume or port capacity that is currently being taken and if you've seen I guess this will be the oldest sites or earlier sites whether you're seeing customers going back and incr
componenttext: Can you just talk about your Fiber-to-the-Cell business to sort of capacity volume or port capacity that is currently being taken and if you've seen I guess this will be the oldest sites or earlier sites whether you're seeing customers going back and increasing capacity commitments and how these trends are playing out. And then just on the SMB side, just kind of get a clarification whether the pricing activity that you put into place was pricing up or pricing down to the competition.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: In the Fiber-to-the-Cell, yes, the capacity continues to grow. In some cases, customers who came in early are expanding when they're already installed. And others are coming in higher. So it's been phenomenal. Actually, it's been amazing for me, and it's
componenttext: In the Fiber-to-the-Cell, yes, the capacity continues to grow. In some cases, customers who came in early are expanding when they're already installed. And others are coming in higher. So it's been phenomenal. Actually, it's been amazing for me, and it's driven by all the wireless devices that are coming out and all the activity that you see in the market. But it's increasing quickly as far as the speeds that everybody needs. On the small business side, it was a combination. We did raise prices on some legacy products, and we declined and bundled some of our new services. So the combination of both, up and down, which netted it out, as you could see in the results there.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Just following up on the Fiber-to-the-Cell question, can you tell me about what kind of revenue growth do you expect just through from new sites versus on the existing sites for existing customers?
componenttext: Just following up on the Fiber-to-the-Cell question, can you tell me about what kind of revenue growth do you expect just through from new sites versus on the existing sites for existing customers?

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we're pushing -- I really probably can't answer that right now, because as you look at the cell sites, there's copper going in there right now that the customer has, and we moved some of that out and put the fiber in and looking for it to net some
componenttext: Yes, so we're pushing -- I really probably can't answer that right now, because as you look at the cell sites, there's copper going in there right now that the customer has, and we moved some of that out and put the fiber in and looking for it to net some growth in the years to come. But it's a change-out that occurs on each individual site. And of course, we love it if the carrier puts up new sites. We can go fiber to that.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks, everybody, for joining us today. I know you got a busy day ahead of you. So we do appreciate you taking your time with us this morning. Please feel free to give us a call in Investor Relations, if you have any follow-on questions that we can
componenttext: Okay, thanks, everybody, for joining us today. I know you got a busy day ahead of you. So we do appreciate you taking your time with us this morning. Please feel free to give us a call in Investor Relations, if you have any follow-on questions that we can help you with this morning. Thanks, and have a great day, guys. Bye.

headline: Qwest Communications International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, that does conclude today's conference call, and we thank you for your participation.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, that does conclude today's conference call, and we thank you for your participation.
